R.C. Indian Day School,
Big River Reserve,
Vicotre, Sask.
Nov. 30, 1942.

Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Canada.

Gentlemen,

Already two months have elapsed since the opening of school and I have as yet received no salary.

If there are any forms to fill in before I can receive any payment, kindly send them to me, because, being very short of money I would like to receive the salaries for the two past months as soon as possible.

Respectfully yours,
Sister Cecilia [signature]
(Teacher)
Regina, December 3rd, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I wish to inform you that I have just received a letter from the Reverend Father G.E. Paquette, O.M.I., at Big River, stating that the Reverend Sister Cecilia de Jesus, the teacher at the Big River Indian Day School, has not received her salary for the month of October.

Will you please look into the matter and advise me but I presume that you are only paying the teacher every three months. In any event let me know what is the system you are working under.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA,
Ont.

December 9, 1948.

Mr. M. Christianson, Gen. Supt. of Indian Agencies,
Dominion Public Bldg., Searth & Victoria, Regina, Sask.

With reference to your letter of the 3rd instant, cheque 50136 in payment of the salary of Rev. Sister Cecilia de Jesus, teacher at the Big River Indian Day School, was forwarded to her on the 28th ultimo. We pay salaries of day school teachers monthly, but the delay in paying her October salary was due to the fact that she had not forwarded the necessary T.D. 1 and cost-of-living bonus forms. These were received about the end of November and, as stated above, cheque for the two months has been forwarded to her and future payments will be made monthly.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Re: Lachance Boy

Therefore please send this boy home and advise him to attend the Catholic school, as he was baptized a Catholic.

Yours Truly,

Shell River, Sask.

Jan. 5, 1943

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

Will you please explain to me article 10-2, page 6 of the Indian Act, and also the decision of the Indian Agent at Leask as given on the enclosed copy.

The reason for this is that Frank Pappiwin, a protestant, and Chief of this Reserve wants to send his nephew, also an anglican protestant, to this school, and, after reference to the above mentioned article and letter I refused to accept him. Kindly let me know if you approve my refusal.

Respectfully yours,

[Signature]

Sister Cecilia of Jesus (Duck)
Ottawa,
January 18, 1943.

Sister Cecilia of Jesus, Teacher, R.C. Indian Day School, Big River Reserve, Victoire, Sask.

With reference to your letter of the 5th instant, Section 10 (2) of the Indian Act refers particularly to the placing of children in Indian residential schools. However, when there are day schools of different religious denominations on the same reserve it has always been our general practice to insist that the Catholic Indian children attend the Catholic day school on the reserve and the Protestant Indian children attend the Protestant Indian day school. Consequently the action you have taken in regard to the case you mention is correct.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Dear Sir,

In the above-named reserve there are two schools, one operated by the Roman Catholics, the other by the Anglicans. In nearly all cases, children of Roman Catholic parents attend their school; the Anglican children there. In one or two cases however, children are close to the Roman Catholic school, and three or four miles from the school of their religious denomination. The opposite condition exists also.

Father Bequet, of the Roman Catholic mission informs me that it is the ruling of the authorities that under no condition must children of one denomination attend the other school. This ruling, if strictly adhered to, causes hardship and sometimes involves risk to the child in severe weather.

I am asking that permission be given for children to attend the school nearest to their home. This would affect very few children of
this minute,

I am, Sir,

your very truly,

Chief Papaweenen. X.
Ottawa,
January 19, 1943.

Mr. T.B. Prince, In Charge Indian Agency,
Leask, Sask.

The Department is in receipt of a letter from Chief Papeweenan of the Big River Reserve in which he asks permission for the children on that reserve to attend the school nearest their home.

When there are day schools of different religious denominations on the same reserve it has always been our general practice to insist that Catholic Indian children attend the Catholic day school on the reserve and Protestant Indian children attend the Protestant Indian day school. At the present time the Department does not see any reason for making a change in this practice and you should so inform the Chief.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa,
January 19, 1943.

March 8, 1943.

REPORT FOR THE MONTH OF FEBRUARY, 1943.

Both schools on Big River Reserve were visited.

The attendance was very satisfactory. A noted improvement in cleanliness of the children was particularly noted at the Catholic School. The sisters are doing real good work in renovating used army clothing for the children. Both schools were supplied with clothing for the children during the early part of the winter.

T.B. Prince,
Clerk in Charge.
Dear Sir:

I was really surprised when the Sister Superior told me that part of the salary had been retained for the income tax.

You know very well the teaching Sisters belong to a religious corporation and as such are exempted from the income tax. Besides, the Sister who is teaching is helped by two other sisters and they support themselves on the salary of the Sister who is teaching. Could you explain me why they are to pay the income tax? The Sister Superior assures me their Rev. Provincial Sister at Prud'homme has a special form certifying that the religious corporation of the "Filles de la Providence" is exempted from the income tax in the teaching profession. Thus, in this province of Saskatchewan, the Rev. Sisters "Filles de la Providence" are teaching at Doremy, Cowville, St-Front, Perigord, Wonda and so forth and they are exempted from the income tax. I do not see why the Rev. Sisters here, on the Big-River I.R., are not exempted from the income tax?

Would you be kind enough to look over this matter and the Rev. Sisters will appreciate very well what you will be done for the investigation.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES

INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH

OTTAWA, ONT.

Rev. Sisters Baisie offers is the School Teacher
MEMO

Members of religious institutions which are incorporated under the laws of the Dominion or of one of the Provinces of Canada, or which are authorized auxiliary institutions of recognized religious communities, are not liable to Income Tax or to National Defense Tax upon any income which they receive and which they place at the disposal of their institution, Order or Community when:

1. a contract is entered into by the religious institution itself, whereby it undertakes to supply, a parish, a school commissioner or an hospital, etc., with a certain number of its members, and the contract expressly stipulates that the salary attached to the service to be rendered by such member is payable solely to the institution that has entered into the contract.

2. a contract is entered into by the individual member of the religious institution and the parish, school commissioner, hospital, etc., by virtue of which remuneration is paid directly to the contracting member and the member receiving such income belongs to a religious institution, order or community which requires him to take a vow of perpetual poverty.

JAM/AG
BIG-RIVER, I.R.
VICTOIRE, P.O., SASK.

Dear Sir:

I was really surprised, when the Sister Superior told me that part of the salary had been retained for the income tax.

You know that the teaching sisters belong to a religious corporation and as such are exempted from the income tax. Besides, the Sister who is teaching, is helped by two other sisters and they support themselves on the salary of the Sister who is teaching. Could you explain me why they are to pay the income tax? The Sister Superior assures me their Rev. Provincial Sister at Prud'homme has a special form certifying that the religious corporation of the "Filles de la Providence" is exempted from the income tax in the teaching profession. Thus in this province of Saskatchewan, the Rev. Sisters "Filles de la Providence" are teaching at Doremy, Prud'homme Leoville, St-Front, Perigord and so on and they are exempted from the income tax. I do not see why the Rev. Sisters, here, on the Big-River I.R. are not exempted from the income tax?

Would you be kind enough to look over this matter and the Rev. Sister will thank you very much for the investigation.

Yours very truly,

Sgd. Fr. G. E. Paquette, O.M.I.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I have received a letter, copy of which is herewith attached, regarding Income Tax deductions from the salary of the Sister Superior at the Big River R.C. Indian Day School.

We interviewed the Income Tax office concerning this and they have given us a Memorandum regarding the regulations concerning members of religious institutions whose incomes are insured.

I would therefore ask you to look into this matter and make the necessary adjustment.

[Signature]

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa, May 11, 1943.

M. Christianson, Esq.,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies,
Dominion Public Building,
cor. Scarth & Victoria Sts.,
Regina, Sask.

I wish to acknowledge your letter of May 7, file 303-11, enclosing the letter of May 6 from the Reverend Father G.M. Paquette, O.M.I., in connection with income tax deductions from the salary of the Reverend Sister Cecilia of Jesus, teacher at the Big River R.C. Indian Day School.

With regard to the ruling of the Department of National Revenue, Income Tax Division, the Indian Affairs Branch have not deducted income tax from the salaries of Sisters of recognized religious corporations engaged as teachers if the Branch is advised of the facts when the appointments are made. The Cost of Living Bonus regulations do not permit of payment of cost of living bonus to institutions and, where teaching Sisters, members of recognized religious corporations, have claimed exemption from income tax, the cost of living bonus has not been paid.

In the case of the Reverend Sister Cecilia of Jesus, cost of living bonus has been paid in addition to salary and the deductions made on account of income tax; in other words, the Sister has been treated in the same manner as any other employee of the Indian Affairs Branch.

From the letter of the Reverend Father G.M. Paquette, O.M.I., it is noted that the compensation paid is used by the Reverend Sister for her maintenance and is not turned over to the religious corporation.

I would appreciate if you would explain the above to the Reverend Father Paquette and advise the Indian Affairs Branch further in this respect.

Director.
Dept. of Mines & Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Sister Cecilia had to leave on April 1943 on account of serious illness. Doctors prescribed complete rest after three months at the hospital. We provided right away another teacher.

If at that time we failed to inform the Indian Agent's office, I apologize for it.

The teacher now in charge of the school is,

Sister Marie-Reine (Leray).

Hoping this will be satisfactory, I remain,

dear Sir.

Yours truly,

Mother Superior,

Victoire, Sask.

BIG-RIVER, I.R.
VISTOIRE, P.G., SASK.,
June 6th 1944

HONORABLE MINISTER:

I was surprised, yesterday, to know that the salary of the sister teaching at the Big-River I.R. R. School was but ninety two dollars while usually it was one hundred and seventeen. There must have been an error. Lately, the name of Sister Cecilia of Jesus was changed to that of Sister Marie Rose, on the cheque. Perhaps it was believed that the latter has no dependents. But the three Sisters working here on the reserve live upon the salary of the one who is teaching. As they have expenses to meet too, you understand that the teacher has a right to her full salary.

Lately, the Indian Agent, Mr. Jones, even remarked that the Reverend Sister deserved an increase of salary considering all the work they do here. You may, thus, judge of their surprise and deception upon seeing the cheque amounting but ninety two dollars.

Could you please give us a reason for this change or see if there is not an error to rectify, as soon as it will be possible.

I thank you sincerely, Honorable Minister for the service you shall render and I remain very truly.

Dear Father Paquette:

Your letter of the 20th ultimo, regarding salary payments to the teachers of the Big River R.C. School for the period April 1 to October 31, has been received and very carefully reviewed.

It is true that religious teaching orders have been exempted from the payment of income tax. However, when members of a religious order claim that privilege we are not permitted to pay bonus.

The small income tax deduction of $4.05 made in April was due to the fact that Sister Cecilia of Jesus had filed a T.D. 1 form stating that she had two dependents. We noted that she referred to the two Sisters associated with her in the work. These cannot legally be claimed as dependents. The classification consequently was debatable but, in order not to delay forwarding the cheque, she was considered as having two dependents and consequently only $4.05 income tax was deducted. An official ruling was obtained in May to the effect that the two other Sisters engaged with her in the work did not actually constitute dependents and consequently the full tax deduction of a single person without dependents was made.

Dear Sir:

I already sent a copy of this report to one of my friends, Mr. Lionel Bertrand, member for Terrebonne. However, he advises me to address myself to a deputy from the West. As you are one of the two liberal deputies of Saskatchewan, I address myself to you, certain that you will help me and that you will use your influence at the Indian Department to obtain the favor that I ask.

Now here is the question: It would be to enlarge the actual school by thirty feet in order to keep the children free Monday morning till three thirty on the next Friday. Mr. Jones, the Indian Agent, is doubtful as he is not able to know what the authorities of the Roman Catholic Church think. After having taken information, I wish to say that the authorities of the R.C. Church are not opposed to it and they even told me to go ahead. I do not ask for a boarding school, but a reform day school according to the expression of Mr. Jones, a school like the one at Fort Pelly.

Now, here are the reasons I bring forth to get a reform day school:

1. The actual school is too small, for the exterior measurements of the school are twenty-five feet wide and thirty-eight feet long. Then the average attendance at school is also twenty-two usually the number of the pupils varies from twenty-five to thirty-two every day. Furthermore, there are only twenty-eight desks. It is really troublesome for the teacher to supervise, when the children are two in a desk. Since nearly two months the Sister Superior teachers the beginners in the basement of the school, which, in winter, is too cold and of which the floor is out of use. The Sisters asked for times, I think, to have the floor repaired and they, always, had the same reply from the Indian Agent: no money, next year, we will try to do something. It is a good escape from requisition.

2. Since January 1939, I was obliged nearly every day to go around in order to have the children come to school. It was a real corvee. Since September 1945, with the help of the family allowances, the children come to school more willingly, but they are late and I have to continue the same strategy: get the children at home in order to have them come on time for the beginning of school.

3. Nearly every morning, the children arrive at school very dirty. The Sisters take three quarters and often an hour making them (the children) wash and clean themselves. This causes a lateness for school.
4. Some parents keep their children because they are too far to go to school every day. When hunting time season comes, every one leaves the reserve and there are no children or few at school.

5. The children whose father or mother is dead will have an opportunity to attend and to have a home for, at least, five days in a week.

6. Keeping the children for five days in a week, they will make more progress and it will not be a trouble for the teacher to begin every morning the lesson explained the day before.

7. Finally, the money given for the Family Allowance will be useful to the children. Otherwise, the parents use it to buy anything and the children are the last served. Very often, the children come to school after having eaten only a little food which renders impossible all effort in school.

For these reasons, I think that a school where we would keep the children from Monday morning till Friday afternoon and which would be something like the great units would do a great deal of good to the children.

A reform day school will be an honour to the Indian Department, which, at this time, seems to be the aim of criticisms from every one, and the Indians would derive the greatest profit from it.

As you can see, while reading these lines, the project is worth while trying, and I dearly hope that you will use all the influence you have so that the little Indian children of the Big River Reserve learn and be able to enjoy the benefits of the education received at the reform day school.

Thanking you in advance for what you will do and I am,

Yours truly,

(sgd.) G. E. Paquette, O.M.I.
(Father)

Dear Mr. Tucker:

I am in receipt of your letter of March 21, enclosing communication which you have received from Reverend G. H. Paquette, O.M.I., Big River Indian Reserve.

In his communication Father Paquette suggests enlarging the present school so as to provide accommodation for keeping the children from Monday to Friday, instead of allowing them to go home each evening. To adopt his suggestion would actually mean the establishment of a residential school, because we would be expected to provide proper sleeping accommodation, supply meals and increase the staff so that the children would receive proper care. My officials do not favour this suggestion as the Big River Roman Catholic School was constructed some years ago with the thought in mind that the children would remain on their home reserve and it would not be necessary to place them in a residential school.

Father Paquette appears to be under the impression that if such a school were started the amount paid for family allowances could be used for the maintenance of the children at such an institution. Evidently, he is not aware that family allowances are not paid in the case of children enrolled at an Indian residential school.

With regard to the other complaints made in Father Paquette's letter, I am requesting the Director of the Indian Affairs Branch to communicate with the Indian agent.

Yours sincerely,

Mr. Walter Tucker, M.P.,

Dear Mr. Bertrand:

When we met last summer at Ste.-Therese, I spoke to you about a project regarding the Catholic School of the Big River Reserve. You answered: Send me a report and I will submit it to the Minister of National Resources. As it was stopped by my work and trips, I could not do it before the last few days. This was the cause of my delay. Now here is the question: It would be to enlarge the actual school by thirty feet in order to keep the children from Monday morning till three thirty on the next Friday. Mr. Jones, the Indian Agent, is doubtful as he is not able to know what the authorities of the Catholic Church think. After having taken information, I wish to say that the authorities of the Catholic Church are not opposed to it and they even told me to go ahead. I do not ask for a boarding residential school, but a Reform Day School according to the expression of Mr. Jones, a school like the one at Fort Pelley.

Now here are the reasons I bring forth to get a Reform Day School:

1. The actual school is too small, for the exterior measurements of the school are twenty-five feet wide and thirty-eight feet long. Then the average attendance at school is about twenty-two, usually the number of pupils varies from twenty-two to thirty-two every day. Furthermore there are only twenty-eight desks. It is really troublesome for the teacher to supervise, when the children are two in a desk. Since nearly a month, the Sister Superior teaches the beginners in the basement of the school, which, in winter, is too cold and of which the floor is out of use. The Sisters asked four times I think, to have the floor repaired and they always had the same reply from the Indian Agent: - No money, next year we try to do something. It is a good escape from the requisition.

2. Since January 1939, I was obliged nearly every day to go around in order to have the children come to school. It was a real corvee. Since September, 1945, with the help of the family allowances, the children come to school more willingly, but they are late and I have to continue the same strategy: get the children at home in order to have them come on time for the beginning of school.

3. Nearly every morning, the children arrive at school very dirty. The Sisters take three quarters and often an hour making them (the children) wash and clean themselves. This causes a lateness for school.

4. Some parents keep their children because they are too far to go to school every day. When hunting time comes, every one leaves the reserve and there are no children or few at school.

5. The children whose father or mother is dead will have an opportunity to attend school and to have a home for, at least, five days in a week.

6.
6. Keeping the children for five days in a week they will make more progress and it will not be a trouble for the teacher to begin every morning the lesson explained the day before.

7. Finally, the money given for the family-allowances will be useful to the children. Otherwise, the parents use it to buy anything and the children are the last served. Very often, the children come to school after having eaten only a little, which renders impossible all effort in school.

For these reasons, I think that a school where we would keep the children from Monday morning till Friday afternoon and which would be something like the great school units highly recommended in Saskatchewan, would do a great deal of good to the children and would not be a cause of worry for the teacher. Will there be children or not at school today? Will they be clean?

A reform day school will be an honor to the Indian Department which, at this time, seems to be the aim of criticism from everyone and the Indians would derive the greatest profit from it.

As you can see while reading these lines, the project is worth while trying and I dearly hope that you will use all the influence you have so that the little Indians of the reserve learn and be able to enjoy the benefits of the education received at the Reform Day School.

Thanking you in advance what you will do and

I am, Yours

G. E. Paquette, O.M.I.

Dear Mr. Glen,

On April 23rd you answered to a letter which I had sent you on the 9th of the same month, transmitting to you a letter which had been addressed to me by Reverend Father G.E. Paquette of the Big River Indian Reservation, Saskatchewan.

Father Paquette whom I know intimately, has just sent me a few commentaries in connection with this letter, and I am transmitting them to you as follows:

"In my letter, I did not mention the building of a boarding school outside of the Reservation or the sending of the children to a boarding school outside of the Reservation. All that I asked was this: My request had to do with the enlargement of the present school by about thirty feet in order to keep the children there from Monday to Friday. Then, I mentioned the reasons for which I made that request. There is a reason to which I draw the attention of the Department. The children arrive in a condition verging on filth. The three nuns spend one hour every morning cleaning them. Uninteresting work to which the twelve years of missionary life among the Indians have failed to accustom me, and the nuns start this work again every morning and change their (the children's) clothes, in order that they be properly dressed. Those clothes are gifts which they got, and Mr. Ostrander also sent a few bundles. Once the school day is over, they put on their dirty clothes to go back to the house.

That request does not come from me. It comes from the Indians themselves. Already a family from that Reservation have sent their seven children to the boarding school of Beauval; another made such a request and, this Summer, the Gilbert and Alex Keenatch families want to send their children to the Beauval residential school. Recently, another family made the same request. Since the Department for Indian Affairs wish the children to stay on the Reservation, they must take the means of seeing that they do stay on their own reservation. I forgot to mention how many times the nuns have kept the children or rather have sheltered them during their absence, in order that the children might be at..."
school every day. I have no doubt that the Indian Affairs department can meet my request and will do everything in their power for the welfare of the children.

"I willingly admit that I was unaware of the fact that the children going to a boarding school were not entitled to family allowances. However, I can affirm that I have never seen the Indians in such a condition of idleness as since they receive the family allowance. They rely only on the allowance cheque to live. With that money they are enabled to buy everything they want, and the children have nothing to wear and nothing to eat. Repeated visits to the Reservation would convince anyone who is not aware of the facts, I have never seen them as poor as this summer, and it seems to me that if that money or the equivalent were used to feed and clothe the children, it would be more useful to the children than encouraging the parents to be idle.

"Regarding the third paragraph, concerning the co-operation of the merchants, that is a big question mark because I have noted that the co-operation is very small or does not exist at all".

I again bring this case to your attention, and I think that it will be possible for you to grant the request of this good priest whose family, living at Ste. Thérèse in my county, count among my best friends.

Cordially yours,

Lionel Bertrand

M.P. Terrebonne.

Dear Sir,

Recently I wrote you stating that I would again take up the matter of the Catholic school of Big River reservation. First of all, it is too small, because at the last trimester (from Sent. to December) the pupils' average was 29.9. There are only 28 desks. What can be done when there are 32 to 34 children present in the classroom. As you can see the school is at its full capacity and the ventilation is defective in view of the large number of pupils. Only one class-room for all of them. The Revd. Sister Superior also teaches the highest and lowest courses in the basement of the school to assist the school teacher in her work. Regarding the basement, the cement floor is in very bad condition. The sisters have called the attention of the inspector and of the Indian agent. They examine, make plans and go away; in the Fall or in the Spring repairs will be done. We have been waiting for those repairs for three or four years. It seems that something should be done and the matter would be settled. Nice words and promises. They are well able to give them, our good agents ....

To come back to the letter from Mr. Glen who states: "We are trying to encourage the Indians to accept some responsibility in the education of their children". I wonder if the minister, Mr. Glen, has visited all the reservations of Western Canada. Undoubtedly, some of them are more civilized than others, when they are compared to those of the East which have a civilization of 2 or 3 hundred years before them. That counts for something.

In that connection, an employee of the Indian department mainly admitted: our officers in Ottawa do not understand anything. They judge the western reserves in the same light as those of the east. Without Indians deeply anchored in their habits and whose object is to enjoy the moment's satisfaction, it is very hard for them to understand what it is to be responsible in the education of
their children. As soon as the children have reached the age of 14 or 13, their studies are over. They know enough to saw a piece of wood or to spend their time doing nothing. With the girls, it is the same thing because at the age of 13 or 14 they are already married by their parents. Here are some names, if he wants some:

Catherine Lachance Married under the Indian manner, in February last; born on October 9, 1932.

Naney Whitefish or Attikamen Married in the Indian manner in July last; born Feb. 22, 1933.

Netmaker F. Married in the Indian manner at the age of 14.

Thomas M. Married in the Indian manner at the age of 13 or 14.

Those marriages are for the year 1946 until today. I do not dare bring up cases of the past years.

Under such circumstances, how can you expect the parents to understand their responsibility. Since 1939 almost, as a truant officer handling a stick, I have to walk a mile or two to send the children to school. Unless I did that, they would arrive at twelve o'clock or they would not come at all. Sometimes I have to parley with the parents who want to keep their children for the smallest of reasons. As you can see, civilization has a long way to go before the parents understand their responsibility regarding the education of their children.

Furthermore, the minister of Resources adds: "In a day school of this size it has been felt that the children are happier and more contented in their classes than in a residential school, where they are often far from their parents and homes." First, I want to point this out: I am not asking for a residential school but a semi-residential school, according to the minister's word. Furthermore, I am not making a request for a semi-residential school outside the reserve, but for one on the reserve. That is what the minister seems to ignore. That school will be for the children of the reservation, that is to say, for the Big River reservation commonly known as Whitefish, and not for the children of other reserves. Second point, the children will be happier
and more contented than those of the residential schools. A big interrogation mark can be placed here. A sure thing is that the children kept at school during the whole week will be happier and more contented than those fed at home because, at least, at the school they will satisfy their hunger as, at the house, it is no longer the parents who support their children but rather the children themselves, by the family allowance cheque, who support the parents and keep them in a condition of semi-idleness. Enquire of the merchants of Lascal and of Victoire. They will say what I have just told you and even that a good number spend their family allowance cheque before they receive it.

Happiness from the material viewpoint is very small and can hardly exist. Furthermore at lunchtime (for which the department grants $65 for 34 or 35 children) the children devour what the nuns contrive to give them as if they had hardly or not eaten in the morning before coming to school... The nuns could give you much information in this regard which would surprise you greatly. As you can see, happiness is far from being what the minister thinks. Finally, certain Indian families ardently wish to send their children to an industrial school. Already, since two years, seven or rather then, have gone to such a school. Others have made requests to that effect. I refused and asked the Indian agent, Mr. Jones, to support me in my refusal. That means that the Indians know very well that their children will be happier and more contented in a residential school than in a day-school. It is for the purpose of trying to obtain a semi-residential school or a reform day school, according to the word used by Mr. Jones, Indian agent at Leask, that I bring up the matter again.

I hope that you will send to Mr. Glen the various remarks that I make in this letter and that you will support my request with all your influence. If, one day, the Indian children have a semi-residential school, they will owe it to you and will be glad to thank you by asking God for the graces that you need and for success in your undertakings.

Thanking you very much, I remain,

Yours truly,

R. F. G.E. Paquette, O.M.I.

Dear Sir,

You will undoubtedly recall that I wrote you in the past concerning Reverend Father G.E. Paquette, O.M.I., who ministers to the Indian Reserve at Grande Victoire, Saskatchewan.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

Please advise me whether the Department has decided upon a definite policy with regard to the attendance of Indian children at day schools where there are two day schools on the same reserve, one operated under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church, and the other operated under the auspices of a Protestant denomination.

A situation has arisen at the Big River Reserve of the Carlton Agency whereby Reverend Father Paquette, who is the Roman Catholic Missionary on that reserve, has raised an objection to Roman Catholic children attending the Anglican Indian Day School. I may say in this connection that we have two Indian day schools on the White Bear's Reserve, one under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church, and the other under the auspices of the Women's Missionary Society of the United Church. There was an understanding when the Roman Catholic Day School was opened last year that parents of children living closer to the Roman Catholic School should be permitted to send their children to that school, even though they belong to the United Church, and that parents of Roman Catholic children living closer to the United Church School should be permitted to send their children to the United Church School rather than have them travelling a greater distance to the school operated under their own denomination.

I certainly favour this method as it seems unnecessary, even unwise, to insist upon Indian children travelling a greater distance to school in order that they may attend the school of their own denomination.

Dear Sir,

Reverend Father G.E. Paquette, O.M.I., ministerant at Big River, Indian Reservation, in Saskatchewan, and who comes from my own city, calls the following facts to my attention and asks me to make them known to you. In his letter he states:

"Since September, we have difficulty in getting certain children to attend school. They say that at the Anglican school they can stay away as much as they like and that the family allowance is granted to them just the same. The Department has set five days for absenteeism per month. If the children are absent over five days per month, they do not get the allowance. At the school here, the teacher is strict about this. Last fall, young Sam Lachance of the Anglican school spent almost two weeks in front of the Catholic school waiting for the pupils to go and play. The nuns have, like myself, seen young Lachance play truant. The allowance was granted for that month such as in the case of the pupils who attend school regularly. I would not have said a word if the councillor Thomas Whitefish whose children go to the Anglican school had not stated before three or four Indians at our school, "at the Anglican school the children are absent as often as they like and the allowance is granted regularly". That is a source of annoyance for us and it seems to me that the same law must apply to the children of other denominations as well as to the Catholic pupils."
Recently an Indian woman, Mrs. Benjamin Netmaker went to the Ste. Famille hospital at Prince Albert. After having been examined, the doctors stated that she took too great a quantity of Indian medicine and that her internal tissues are destroyed. That is what Dr. Tucker of Prince Albert, said here to a family on the reserve, and he tried to find out who gave her the medicine. First, this woman got Indian remedies from Frank Netmaker and in addition, he bled her at the elbow. I have proofs concerning what I state. Then, Charlie Lachance also gave her medicine. When they have wheedled as much money as possible from the patient and when they see that there is no more hope, those two men call for a doctor and, if the latter is not successful, they accuse him of being inefficient, etc. I think that this is the good time to bring those two nitwits to their senses, particularly in this case; it is thought, according to the doctor's report, that the woman has blood poisoning. I would ask the Indian Department to get busy and to see that the two men get severe punishment. Then the whites who live near the reservation will stop to believe that the Indian Department is not doing its duty in this respect and that the Department appoints unqualified doctors to look after the Indians".

I believe that those facts certainly deserve your personal consideration and that of your Department. Hoping to hear from you soon, I remain,

Yours truly,

Lionel Bertrand.

Big River Indian Reserve.

I am now able to provide you with further information concerning the situation mentioned in my letter of April 19.

You will recall that the Reverend Father G. E. Paquette, O.M.I. of the Big River Indian Reserve, made certain representations with regard to conditions on this reserve. The delay in answering has been caused by the fact that our field officials have been unable to reach the reserve because of the condition of the roads. However, we have now received a report from our Indian Superintendent and also from the teacher of the Church of England school on the Big River Reserve.

The essential fact in this situation seems to be that some members of the Big River Band have refused to accept family allowances. For this reason, our field officials have not pressed the regulations regarding school attendance. In this way it was hoped that the parents would be encouraged to register their children for payment.

The teacher at the Big River Church of England School is an Indian named Mr. Smith Atimoyoo who is a graduate in Theology from Emmanuel College. He has submitted a report upon his pupils' attendance during the year. Unfortunately, this
report was delayed because of lack of transportation and the flooded river.

It shows that Sam Lachance was absent during September because of toxoid illness.

Our local Indian Superintendent will be giving special attention to the attendance at this school in future.

Yours sincerely,

A.G.L. Adams,
Private Secretary.

We have now received Mr. Provincial Inspector Amundrud's report on the above school. In his general comment he states as follows:

"From money won as prizes for work exhibited at the Prince Albert fair last summer a full set of rhythm band instruments has been secured. I was rather impressed with the quality of performance with these instruments and also with the fact that every child took part. Considerable time is now being spent in learning Christmas songs also. This is commendable, although I did feel since the learning of English presents sufficient difficulty, that the learning of songs in Latin is unnecessarily burdensome.

Pupils in the higher grades read sufficiently well to understand and do problems from their texts. Reading in the primary grades tends to be word-saying, not too closely associated with the meaning since English is heard and spoken only within the classroom. If the obstacles are not too great, I would suggest that English rather than Cree be the language of the playground also.

The schoolhouse is as usual very clean and well kept.

The furnace smokes too readily and should be repaired.

In order to free the one cloakroom for its intended use I would suggest the building of storage cupboards across the back of the classroom."
Would you please discuss with Sister Marie Ladislas the possibility of having the Indian children use English on the playgrounds rather than Cree. We realize only too well the difficulty involved in this but would appreciate a redoubling of her efforts to have English spoken. It is presumed that we will be hearing from you with regard to the furnace. Would it be possible to have a tender obtained for the installation of the storage cupboards required, or would you suggest the purchase of an unpainted cupboard from Eaton's or Simpson's?

Dear Mr. Castleden:

I have for answer your letter of April 7 addressed to the Superintendent of Education. The information which you requested is as follows. On the Big River Reserve there are two day schools in operation. One of these is for the Roman Catholic children (the 1944 census shows 199 Catholics) and one for the Anglican children (the census shows 65 Indians for this denomination).

Both schools are located on the reserve about a mile and a half apart. They are identical in size and structure, but the classroom operated for the Roman Catholic children is crowded, and we are now investigating the possibilities of enlarging it. The teacher at the Anglican school is an Indian named Smith Athayoo who attended high school in Prince Albert and then attended Emmanuel College for a period of four years. There he received his Associate in Theology. He taught at the Shoal Lake Indian Day School from 1942 to 1947. He began teaching at the Big River C.M. Indian Day School in September, 1947.

The teacher at the Big River R.C. Indian Day School is Sister Marie Ladislas. She holds a First Class Teaching Certificate for the Province of Saskatchewan and has had three years of experience in private and provincial schools. She was appointed to this position on the 1st September, 1948, and replaced Sister Bernadette Karle who also had a First Class Teaching Certificate with some ten years of experience in provincial schools.

Our Educational Survey Officer spent a considerable part of last Spring in Saskatchewan, and as a result of his inspections, we are planning the building of a number
of day schools in that province. As you are aware, we have completed the schools at Meadow Lake, Nut Lake and Poorman. The new two-room school at Thunderchild is just now beginning construction.

We will shortly be advertising for tenders for other schools.

These schools are inspected by both the Provincial School Inspectors and by our own Indian Superintendents. The school inspectors naturally concentrate on classroom technique and teaching methods, whereas our superintendents check on the condition of the building, cleanliness of the children and school administration generally.

The Provincial School Inspectors visit these schools at least once a year, and our own superintendents visit them as often as possible, usually once a month.

I hope the above information provides you with the facts you are seeking.

Sincerely yours,

Director.

Enclosed herewith please find a copy of a letter forwarded to this office by the Rev. Father Paquette, R.C. Missionary on the Big River Indian Reserve. The contents thereof is self explanatory.

As you are aware, Big River Band of Indians are served by Anglican and R.C. Missionaries both of whom are struggling to convert the members of Big River Band from Paganism to a christian way of life, with the results that considerable pressure is being brought to bear upon the Indians by the Missionaries concerned to adhere to the particular faith which the Missionaries represent, due to this pressure the Indian mind is confused and while a few are becoming strong adherents of the faiths mentioned, the majority are asea as it were and cannot understand the difference or shall we say animosity that exists between the two christian denominations who are in competition in connection with their conversion from Paganism.

The suggestion outlined in the enclosed letter received from Rev. Father Paquette would no doubt assist the Missionaries and place the onus of deciding which Indian is Pagan, Anglican or Roman Catholic upon our Branch, with the results that the Superintendent would eventually receive the wrath of Anglican and Roman Catholic Church officials. This responsibility I do not feel we should accept nor do I feel that we should expend the taxpayers money to assist either religious denomination now striving in competition to convert the Indians of Big River Band to their respective faith.
The writer has issued a directive to both Anglican and Roman Catholic school teachers as outlined in section 10, subsection 2 of the Indian Act. The teachers report that they have advised the parents of children in attendance at the schools under their charge to the effect that no Protestant child shall be assigned to a Roman Catholic school and no Roman Catholic child shall be assigned to a Protestant school.

The writer has also endeavoured to iron out the difficulty however I find that Indians who at one time adhered to the Anglican faith have been baptised by the Roman Catholic clergy and previous to the coming into Big River Reserve by Roman Catholic Missionaries the Big River Band were recognized as adherents of the Anglican faith, however, I would go so far as to state that Paganism possibly would be the correct term.

Again, referring to the enclosed letter, I believe that our Branch is now being requested to supply transportation with a view towards our accepting responsibility to decide which Indian family is R.C., Anglican or Pagan, thereby leaving ourselves open to criticism in the event of an error arising.

Our day schools on the Big River Indian Reserve are located from three to five miles apart, therefore the solution appear to be for our Missionaries to induce their adherents to place their home near the day schools conducted under their auspices. This method should now be feasible as we have provided materials for the erection of twenty new Indian homes on the Big River Indian Reserve.
The difficulty confronting our Missionaries is a problem that they themselves should solve and the Missionaries concerned must face the fact that the Indians of Big River Band have not advanced towards acceptance of christianity and the Indian's mind is becoming confused to the extent that due to competition in converting them to christianity they have become neither good Pagans, Anglicans or Roman Catholics. This is as explained to the writer by the Chief of Big River Band.

Should you disagree with my views outlined herein I am prepared to act on your instructions. In the meantime I am not prepared to recommend the suggested method of providing transportation as outlined in the enclosed letter from Rev. Father Paquette.

On my next visit to Big River Indian Reserve I will again discuss this matter with Rev. Father Paquette, and, if necessary submit a further report.

N.J. McLeod

BIG RIVER INDIAN RESERVE

Dear Father Plourde:

As you are aware, there are two separate mission groups working on the above reserve, in the Duck Lake Agency, Saskatchewan. Both are endeavouring to convert the members of the Big River Band from paganism to a Christian way of life, with the results that considerable pressure is being brought to bear upon the Indians by the missionaries concerned.

Due to these pressures, the Indian mind is confused and we are advised that while a few are becoming strong adherents of the faiths mentioned, the majority are rather undecided and cannot understand the difference and the feelings which exist between the two Christian denominations who are in competition in connection with their conversion from paganism.

I have discussed with you previously the activities of your missionary, the Reverend Father Paquette, and now wish to bring to your attention another matter which has recently arisen concerning his activities. Recently Mr. Indian Superintendent McLeod has issued a letter to both Anglican and Roman Catholic school teachers, in accordance with Section 10 (subsection 2) of the present Indian Act. The teachers report that they have advised the parents of children in attendance at the schools under their charge concerning the provisions of this section.

The Indian Superintendent has also tried to iron out the difficulty but he has found that Indians who at one time adhered to the Anglican faith have been baptized by the Roman Catholic clergy. This of course has led to a great deal of confusion as to the exact religious status of some of the Indians.
Father Paquette has now made a request with regard to transportation which would place the onus of deciding the religious denomination of the Indian children directly on Departmental officials. The onus of deciding which Indian is pagan, Anglican, or Roman Catholic, would involve the Indian Superintendent in many controversies and would eventually arouse the wrath of both the Anglican and Roman Catholic Church authorities.

As you are aware, the decision with regard to residential school pupils is made on the basis of the application forms completed by the parents and if necessary supported by statutory declarations. This is not possible in the case of day school pupils and it would lead to endless confusion if each day school pupil had to fill out an application form for submission to the Department.

It is evident that the Indians of the Big River Band have not advanced towards acceptance of Christianity and in fact the Chief of the Band has described the situation to the Indian Superintendent in very apt terms. He claims that the minds of the Indians are becoming confused to such an extent, due to competition in converting them to Christianity, that they have become neither good pagans, good Anglicans or good Roman Catholics.

Furthermore, Father Paquette seems to be intent on pressing this matter and on October 31 he wrote to our Indian Superintendent as follows:

"Last Friday I saw the children (Three children) of George Morin and Louis George Morin coming from the Anglican School - I waited one month to know if your instructions will be carried out or not. Now, my first move will be to publicly yours letters and the ones of Mr. Jones - and so on to the new papers, for the way the things are going you are just to fool me. It is my duty to do it and I am taking this opportunity to let you this thing known before I will do anything."
With this explanation in front of you, I would appreciate an interview with you in the near future so that Father Paquette can be advised of the difficulties which he is creating and which it is felt the Department should not decide but rather the missionaries concerned.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Healy,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of a requisition for the supplies and equipment necessary for the operation of the Big River Catholic Indian day school. I note on this requisition you ask for 20 combined seats and desks for school pupils and also 1 kitchen range for preparing midday lunches.

May I express the opinion that you should be reasonably familiar with the regulations governing the purchase of Departmental supplies. It is wholly impossible for Purchasing Agents, who are in no sense familiar with the operations of an Indian day school or, for that matter, any other day school, to purchase seats unless they have before them information indicating the age of the pupils that are likely to use these seats. In the case of the kitchen range I naturally ask whether it is intended to burn wood or coal in this range and ask for additional information with respect to the size, etc. I must again express regret that this information was not forwarded with your requisition. Your failure to send it forward must, of necessity, result in delay in sending forward these supplies and it is just possible delay in the opening of the school.

You are authorized to purchase locally, from firms on the approved list, the other supplies listed on your requisition with the exception of the seats, the stove and the desk and chair for the teacher. Your immediate attention to this matter will be very much appreciated.

Yours truly,

R. S. Davis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Leask, Sask.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

4 desks for pupils 10 years old.
4 desks for pupils 12 years old.
4 desks for pupils 14 years old.

A kitchen range similar to the one shown in Eaton's catalogue on page 407, No. 45 L 100 at $62.75 would be satisfactory for use at this school. Wood will be used for fuel.

As this school is now being erected the opening will not be delayed. It is expected that the school will be ready for use in about a month and a half.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of April 13th in which you advise the teachers to order early and keep expenditure as low as possible.

Your request was followed to the letter, the order mailed to the Indian Agent Mr. R. S. Davis, and to date nothing has been received yet and we are short of everything. This school was opened on January 15th 1940 and we are still without a chair or desk for the teacher, no clock, no bell, not enough desks for the children, no broom, no dust pan, no tub and scores of other things are lacking.

The attendance is over twenty-three now and seven or eight more are expected within a week. How can I carry on without impairing the efficiency of the school.

The Roman Catholic Missionary and the teacher have been supplying whatever they could afford but is it reasonable that they should be forced to do so.

Following my responsibility as a teacher, I feel it my duty to lodge a complaint to your office without however laying the blame on any body in particular, but surely someone is responsible. I find it queer that from a communication from Mr. Phalen through Father Plourde O.M.I. about the pupil's desks: we were told to send our order to the agent and he then would notify Mr. Phalen that our request would be granted. In the mean time, the teacher sent a requisition form asking all what was necessary in the school and the desks were mentioned. No reply from the agent. About at that time, the agent told us to put every thing on the requisition forms and mail to him.
This was done according to his instructions.

I hope that this letter will bring a favorable reply. Thanking you in anticipation for your kind attention.

Yours sincerely

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

Attention Mr. R.A. Hoey

May I call your attention to the case of the Big River R.C. Day School. Although it was opened last January, the teacher has neither desk nor chair; there are no brooms, dust pans, wastepaper baskets; neither is the quantity of school books and writing pads large enough. Moreover the Department only supplied 17 desks and there are at the present time 24 pupils.

The suggestion is made that if the Department cannot supply desks immediately it direct the local Agent to transfer the surplus desks from the Anglican Day School to the Catholic Day School as there are only 8 pupils in the latter at the present time. We wouldn't want it done however if it is to cause any friction between the two groups.

The missionary in charge complains that his Indians have not been fairly treated by the Agent as far as help for his school garden is concerned. It appears that the Agent refused to break the land selected for the garden; neither would he supply wire for fencing it. Again the complaint is made that all these services were rendered to the Anglican school.

There are other minor complaints made against the Agent which I do not think it opportune to include in this letter. I know that you will want to investigate the case and if the statements made to me are true proper corrective measures will be immediately taken.

TRANSLATION:

Shell-River P.O., Oct. 24, 1940.

Mr. H.R. Fleming, M.P.,
Humbolt, Sask.

Dear Mr. Fleming:

I am home after a sick-call 25 miles away and passing at Shell-River at 8 o'clock in the morning I received your letter giving the Minister's answer. No doubt he finds an easy way out, but he does not tell the truth. After having been deceived many times by the Indian Agent we are no further ahead than when the school opened on January 15 last. The Minister states in his letter that "at that time (he mentions the month of February) all the desks which the Indian Agent considered necessary were supplied". Now please note that the children's desks were here at the end of November or at the beginning of December. When the Agent came to the Reserve for the opening of the Anglican School, he could notice that there were not enough desks for the children. That is why he asked the carpenter who built the school and who was building my house, to make a few. As the Agent asked him to do this work for nothing, that is to say without any remuneration whatever, the man refused to do so. He used the same method for the teacher's desk. In November he told me to go to the railway station to call for the teacher's desk which he had ordered. I made two 20-mile trips and there was no desk there. In January he asked the carpenter to make one; for nothing, of course. The man would not; so you see he was knowingly lying when he said he had ordered a desk.

Moreover the school is not finished completely. The shelving is not yet in place and is still in the school basement. A cupboard has been started and not finished. What happened? you will ask. The Agent said he had no more money and would have liked the carpenter to work without remuneration, but he would not do so, you may imagine. The carpenter had to take the paper, paint, wood, etc. in order to receive full payment for the work he did. The Agent would not pay him although he was well satisfied with the work. Many people witnessed this mean scheme of the Agent.

Another question to which I would like to draw your attention is the garden. The teacher agreed to make a garden under the condition that he be supplied with seed, the
ground ploughed and a fence given him. The Agent absolutely refused to give him anything while at Sandy Lake he had the soil ploughed and he gave the seed. He also gave two rolls of barbed wire for a fence and $10 for the work. When he was through he asked: "Is that enough?" As you may see by this instance, there are two ways of treating people.

The Government allows 50 dollars for the children's noon lunch. In the past, the Anglican teacher would order whatever she needed and sent her bill to the Agent. Last year, he offered the teacher money. As the teacher did not know how to go about it he asked the Agent to buy whatever he needed. This year the Agent refused to give him the money and he wants to buy the food for the school here. Moreover we have 29 children registered and just now the daily attendance is 22-24. The Anglican school receives the same amount for about ten children who attend school there. A few days ago the Indians told me that there were seven pupils at the Anglican school. In June last, when the Inspector visited the school, there were four. It was the Inspector at Shell-Lake, Mr. Faris, who told the teacher so. As you can see there is something wrong and it is detrimental to us. Fifty dollars for 25 or 26 Catholic children and fifty dollars for seven to ten Anglican children. Nice way of dividing! Do you think that is just? ...

Last Friday, October 18, the Agent was on the Reserve and met the teacher on his way. As the schoolmaster only asked him for essential things and that they be sent as soon as possible, the Agent answered back: "You are lucky to have it opened" -- speaking of the school. As you can plainly see there is lack of co-operation on his part.

I have been here three years now. I have always tried to be kindly-disposed towards officials of the Indian Affairs Department and except in very few cases, I received very little deference. So in future I will change my attitude and I warn you that they will find me pretty hard. Since a short while I have found a way out and as soon as my mission trips are ended, I will make it a point to make the people learn by newspaper channels the wrongdoings of the Department of Indian Affairs officials on this Reserve. Be assured that I will not flatter them and those officials will
be ashamed for I have a voluminous file. That will be a good way of busying myself at a work that my superiors have asked me to do in Indian.

I am enclosing the list of the articles which have been asked for three times since January 15, but in vain, to the Department of Indian Affairs. The Agent asked us to wait till the end of March and then until September. Nothing has reached us except a few books. The teacher was without books for three months. How can we be expected to work? I added to this list a water pump because the teacher is obliged to carry about ten pailfuls of water every morning from the lake. The Agent insists on manual training. As there are no tools, I thought it was better to mention this on the list.

A few days ago I met Indian women who were going to the Pagan dance for the Dead, called waskasimowin, and they told me that the mocassins and other skin over-shoes would be ready in about two weeks. They asked me if you wanted buttons or zips put on these. Please let them know.

Thanking you, I am

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) G.E. Paquette, O.M.I.

P.S. I am giving you these details in order that you may be posted, for I expect the Agent will have a story all his own. The Anglican school received seven bags of potatoes from the Community Garden and the authorities refuse to give any to the Catholic school.

Dear Sir:

The Department found it necessary to telegraph you yesterday with regard to the non receipt of a reply to official letter of the 18th ultimo. It should be unnecessary for me to point out that unless prompt replies are forwarded to official communications Departmental business is greatly hampered.

Before you receive this letter you will have no doubt replied to official letter of October 18 but subsequent correspondence which has just reached us makes it necessary for me to request another reply at once to the following questions:

1. It is reported that the shelving is not in place and is still in the school basement and that the building of a cupboard has been commenced but not finished. Please let me know at once the reason for this delay.

2. It is reported that the teacher wished to cultivate a garden but that you refused to secure authority for any expenditure although it is reported that you approved an expenditure for the cultivation of a garden at another school in your Agency. There is no information on our file regarding this and you should report fully on this complaint.

3. It is stated that the enrolment at the Big River R.C. School is 29 and that the enrolment at the C.E. School is less than half that number. In spite of this it has been brought to our attention that you have requested authority for the same expenditure at both

Dear Mr. Fleming,

In reply to the letter which you have received from the Department of Indian Affairs, I may say that we have the teacher's desk and the chair.

As to the children's desks, the teacher, to my personal knowledge, has filled out three times the forms which have been sent to him. I find it strange that the Department does not know anything about this.

Concerning the report from inspector Ferris of Shell-Lake, who came here in June last, there were then 29 pupils who had registered (called in English "Enrollment") and there were 17 of them present on that day. On the 6th of November last, Inspector Ferris came around 11:00 o'clock, a few minutes before my leaving to teach catechism. 23 students out of 29 registered children were present in spite of a hopping enough children on the reserve. To convince you, I am sending you a copy of the school register for the months of January, June and November, 1940, and moreover, every morning I see to it that the children are in school although the Indian Act mentions that a "truant" officer be appointed to that effect. As you may see, Inspector Ferris or the members of the Indian Department have impudently lied, which happens too often, alas, and they believe that I will let this go without saying a word. I do not belong to that kind. I hope that you will send this information to the Indian Department to confound their lies.

Regarding the other items, I know that the school teacher has received 2 brooms, one pail, 6 plates, 6 knives, 6 forks, 6 spoons and 6 cups, one tub and a mop. I do not know when the other articles will come.

The agent was here on Friday last. As I had been called to see a patient, he notified the school teacher to inform the carpenter to finish the cupboard and gutters. As you can see there is something wrong somewhere.

In thanking you very much, dear Mr. Fleming, for all you are doing for the Catholic Indians of Big River who attach great importance to what the Canadian Government does for them and assuring you again of the help of my prayers, I remain,

Yours very truly,

(Sgd) G.A. Paquette, O.M.I.

P.S.

(1) The Anglican School received from the "Community Garden" seven bags of potatoes from the Councillor of the reserve without the permission of the Indians. We have received nothing. Only, the farm instructor said: "It is not fair". I have heard nothing else since that time.

(2) I am sending you a copy of the rations given on the reserve by the Department. I hold this information from the farm instructor, and Councillor Thomas Whitefish stated to me that the Indians are not receiving what the farm instructor told me they were getting. The "relief" gives four or five dollars per month to one man in addition to an order to the store for clothes in the fall while a family of two is getting a few dollars per month to live on.

Thank you.

G.A. Paquette, O.M.I.

February 16th, 1941.

H.R. Fleming, Esq., M.D.,
Humbolt, Sask.

Dear Mr. Fleming,

A few days ago I saw the old Half-breed who made the deer skin clothes. She told me that if they do not fit they ought to be returned to her. So, if you would send them back to me I shall bring them to her on my next trip to that mission.

Besides, I asked her to make for me a pair of gloves with beads which I intend giving you. This is a way to thank you for what you have done for my Indians and for what you will do again.

On his last visit here Mgr. Duprat, Bishop of Prince Albert, has not found adequate the room for the schoolmaster here. He made complaints to that effect to the Department and the answer of Mr. Phelan is enclosed.

Here are some of the observations made in Mr. Phelan's letter. "It is possible that the living accommodation for the teacher is not very extensive, but it should be suitable for an unmarried teacher". Here are the facts: The room is 10 ft. by 12 ft. It has a wardrobe 3 feet deep on the full length of the room. There is also a stair 3½ ft. wide which takes some space. As you may see a room 7 ft wide by 10 ft. long is not really an adequate room where the schoolmaster should betake himself. Moreover, the height is 6½ or 7 ft. How do you expect such a room to be hygienic. The rooms of the Prince Albert prison are better than that of the schoolmaster, and add to that defective ventilation. You know also that most of the Indian children are suffering from tuberculosis and venereal diseases. All day long the schoolmaster has to breathe in a bad atmosphere and he is still obliged at night to breathe the same bad air. Finally, he has to use the same table as the children because of the exiguity of the place. It is really dangerous for the teacher to catch venereal diseases. As you may see it is far from being "suitable for an unmarried teacher". I know that it is not pleasant for the schoolmaster to have such a room and not a residence as it is stated by Mr. Phelan.

"It has not been the practice of the Department to erect a teacher's residence separate from the school". I do not ask for a residence separate from the school, but what is convenient for a civilized man. Several rooms could have been easily built in the upper part of the school. It has simply been refused.
The Indian Agent told me himself that the room was not large enough to lodge the schoolmaster and he has encouraged me to ask for a teacher's residence. Mr. Phelan states that it is not the practice to build a house separate from the school. How is it that at Leask, on the Mistawasis reserve, the Department has built a residence for the Anglican schoolmaster and another one for the Presbyterian teacher at Sandy Lake; the Anglican schoolmistress has her own house built by the Department at Sturgeon Lake; the Anglican teacher has also his own residence at Montreal Lake; the same thing exists at Chitek (?) These are reserves that I visit nearly four or five times per year. As you can see, he has boldly lied, if the word can be used among polite people. It is the matter of Catholics asking for something which is turned down, while all kind of help is given to the Anglican Church. We have an average of 20 to 24 students attending the school every day, while the other Anglican school has from 6 to 7 only. The schoolmistress has a nice residence and our teacher here has nothing, absolutely nothing. As you can see that is not fair.

"Due to present conditions" from Mr. Phelan, you know as much as I do, times are hard, I know it, but the government grants some money for roads, etc. It seems to me that the Department could do something for our school here.

I am writing you this letter at the request of the diocese Bishop who insisted that I ask you to take this matter up with the Minister. I already saw Mr. Omer Demers at Debbien about one or two weeks ago. He told me that he was to write you. As I was called to attend sick people on several occasions, it was impossible for me to send you a few words in that connection. I comply today with Mgr. Duprat's wishes and I hope that Providence will help you obtain from the Department what others could not get.

I thank you very much and be assured of the help of my prayers.

Yours truly,

(Sgd.) G.E. Paquette, O.M.I.
Shell River Post Office, Saskatchewan.

P.S.
Could you tell me the size of gloves for your two sons? Perhaps I could have some made for them by the Indians here. Some owe me money. It is the only means to recover it.

I am enclosing Mgr. Duprat's letter. I have kept a copy because before long, if I am authorized to do so by the Bishop, I will write in the newspapers!! I will soon discuss this matter with him. I thank you. Sgd. G.E.P. - O.M.I.

Dear Doctor Fleming:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of February 26 and also copy of a communication received by you from the Reverend S. E. Paquette, C.M.I., of Shell River P. O., Saskatchewan, enclosed therewith.

You are aware that the Roman Catholic and Anglican Indian Day Schools at the Big River Indian Reserve were built in the year 1939. The actual work of construction was undertaken and completed under the direct supervision of Indian Agent Davis. It is to myself and the officials of the Indian Affairs Branch a matter of regret to learn that in the opinion of Father Paquette the living quarters provided for the teacher at the Roman Catholic school appear to be somewhat limited and unsatisfactory from the standpoint of health and sanitation.

This is a matter that could, and no doubt would, be easily adjusted in normal times to the satisfaction of all parties concerned. It is unnecessary to remind you, however, that it is exceedingly difficult in a period as critical as the one in which we find ourselves to secure the funds required to undertake either the construction or the extension of government buildings, particularly so at a time when a number of the provincial governments have placed millions of dollars' worth of buildings at the service of the Dominion Government without cost.

It is our intention to have conditions at the Roman Catholic School at Big River investigated

Dr. H. R. Fleming, M.P.,
House of Commons,
Ottawa.
by the General Superintendent of Indian Agencies,
Mr. H. Christianson, just as soon as he can make
arrangements to undertake this task.

It is very regrettable to learn that
Father Paquette has convinced himself that the schools
operated under the auspices of the Anglican Church in
Saskatchewan appear to receive greater consideration
than the schools operated under the auspices of the
Roman Catholic Church. I am of the opinion that an
earnest attempt should be made to correct this
erroneous impression. When Mr. Phelan, in his letter
to the Bishop of Prince Albert, stated: "It has not
been the practice of the Department to erect a teacher's
residence separate from the school", he really meant
that it is not the general practice to erect detached
and separate residences. The majority of Indian day
school teachers and missionaries throughout the Dominion
have expressed a strong preference for a building con-
taining classroom and teacher's residence, and the
Department has learned from experience that such buildings
are on the whole more economical and more convenient for
the teachers in charge of our schools. In the case of
Montreal Lake, to which Father Paquette refers, a strong
protest against the distance of the teacher's residence
from the school was received a few days ago from the
teacher in charge of that school.

I am sending forward herewith a statement
indicating the number of Indian day and residential
schools in the province of Saskatchewan, the number of
Catholic and non-Catholic schools and the provision made
in the 1941-42 estimates for the upkeep and operation
of these institutions. This statement, you will note,
is self-explanatory and should be sufficient in itself
to remove from Father Paquette's mind any mistaken
impression he may be entertaining with respect to the
assistance extended to the Roman Catholic Church for the
operation of Indian schools in the province of
Saskatchewan.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Doctor Fleming:

Dear Sir:

I wish to refer you to your letter No. 107-13-5 of March 7th in connection with a letter that you wrote to me regarding the Big River R.C. Indian Day School.

In reply, I visited both the above mentioned Roman Catholic School and the Church of England Indian Day School on the Big River Reserve. In the third paragraph of your letter you quote from a letter written by Father Paquette to Dr. H. P. Fleming, M.P., of Humboldt, Saskatchewan. This quotation is absolutely correct with the exception of the second line, where reference is made to a wardrobe 3 ft. deep and the full length of the room. Instead of being a wardrobe, this is a Winnipeg cot on which the teacher has to sleep.

The present incumbent is Mr. R.A. Bonneau. He lives about seven miles from the school and goes home Friday night, returning either Sunday night or Monday morning. He has fourteen children of his own, therefore we would have to have quite a large sized residence to take care of this family, which consists of himself, his wife, and the above mentioned fourteen children, who are all living at home. The oldest, I believe, is about 15. No racial suicide here.

Turning back to the upstairs room of the school, I would refer you to your plans. This room is absolutely useless as a living quarter. You will see this by the size and what the Priest said about it not being a fit place to live on account of the ventilation, the fumes coming up into this small room from the room in which the children have been all day. I am quite sure that everybody will agree with me that this is not a fit room for anybody to sleep in because the stairway is open and allows all the impurities to rise from the room below to the upstairs. However, the present teacher would not move to the school anyway.........
the school anyway because it would be out of the question to build
a house for a man with that sized family. In any event the building
of quarters for the teacher will have to be considered sooner or later.

I note that you state that the school was constructed
under the direct supervision of Indian agent Davis, and to the best of
my knowledge Mr. Davis followed out the plans to the letter and from
what I could see, good workmanship has been performed on both schools.
However, I wish to point out another defect in this institution and
this is that in the Winter time the furnace smokes. The chimney is
built on the outside of the wall and I have always been told by builders
that this was a mistake in a cold climate as the heat from the inside
and the cold from the outside meet in the chimney and form a vapour
which turns into soot, and no doubt during the time when there is no
fire on and the brick chimney is exposed to the weather, a frost forms
on the inside of the chimney during the night and when the fire is put
on the heat naturally thaws out the frost and this is the cause of the
vapour. However, I would suggest that you check this over with
Mr. Dudley, the Architect. You will realize that up around where this
school is located, there is nothing but lakes north of it and I am
sure it become pretty cold in the Winter time. However, instead of
tearing down the chimney and building it inside, which would cost a
great deal, I would ask you to see Mr. Dudley and ask him if the chimney
could be raised up 4 ft. and one of those hoods that change with the
wind put on it, if this would improve the situation any. As far as I
can remember the chimney does not come up as high as the top of the
roof of the school. This may be something to do with the smoking and
we thought that by raising it about 4 ft. and providing a hood for it
as described, it might help, but I am not an expert on this and am
just giving my opinion. There is eaves troughing on the school and the
drain pipe from the eaves troughing which runs along the side of the
building carries all the rain and melting snow down along the basement
wall. I noticed when I was in the basement that the walls on that
side were damp and unless steps are taken to take care of this water
the foundation will be ruined. Mr. Davis offered to look after
this if he were authorized as all that is necessary is to make a trench
and put a pipe in there and connect a down pipe with the sewer pipe.
This will run the water away from the building and as the soil is sandy
it will not be an expensive job by any means, and Indians can be hired
to do the work. I wish to point out in conclusion, that this is important
because there are considerable rain falls in that part of the country.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.
