Dear Sir,

Mr. Christianson was here yesterday to visit the Day School. This is what he said in the presence of the Indian Agent, with regard to the complaints that I had made last winter.

In the first place with reference to the Teacher's room, "He cannot live here" and as to the chimney that does not function well, he added, "This chimney must be moved inside as in this country it is too cold to build a chimney outside".

As you may conclude for yourself, the Secretary for the Minister, who no doubt received his information from the Indian Agent, is really in error when he wrote in his letter, that you were good enough to forward me, "It is a matter of regret to learn that in the opinion of Father Paquette the living quarters provided for the teacher appears to be somewhat limited and unsatisfactory from the standpoint of health and sanitation". I can add that no member of the Indian Department would have lived in a similar pigeon hole from the 8th of January 1940 until this date. This means that a school teacher has lived in an unsanitary room and from that point of view his health has suffered.

In addition to this, Mr. Christianson added that during the war it would be difficult to obtain something from the Department. The Agent informed me that on the 16th of May last not something would be done. I hope that through your influence that you would be able to obtain something for the teacher in order that he will have sanitary and proper apartments.

As to the report regarding the Indian Day School and Residential School there are some remarks which I feel I should make. I quite admit that the total amount allowed by the Government to the Catholics is larger than the amount allowed to the other denominations here. That is quite clear, when you know that there are 1155 Catholic boys attending Industrial schools where they are clothed, nourished and looked after, and I might add that there is not sufficient money allowed for that number of children and on the other hand, the other denominations have only 495. There is no comparison to be made. If the Minister wishes to make comparison he should begin by comparing things on a similar basis. When I refer to Day Schools I am not referring to Industrial Schools or Residential Schools. Let him compare the Day Schools under the direction of Catholics and those under the direction of the Anglicans and I will be in accord with him but not otherwise. From what I have seen at the Leask Agency I realized with my own eyes that there is much more consideration given to the Anglicans than to the Catholics. I hope that I will not be asked to furnish figures but if they wish so, I will be ready to undertake this work.

In addition to this the Minister wrote to you, "It is very regrettable to learn that Father Paquette has convinced himself that the Schools operated under the auspices of the Anglican church in Saskatchewan appear to receive greater consideration than the schools operated under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church". Possibly the Minister himself could inform me of the meeting of the Agents and the Farm Instructors at South Battleford 3 years ago, presided by the then Inspector, Mr. Robertson of Regina, where the question of Industrial Schools was discussed. Why was general sentiment against Industrial Schools?

No doubt.
No doubt the schools of other denominations were suffering financially, whereas those under the Catholic Supervision were prosperous. Where did these ideas come from? I may be mistaken but there are indications that I am not mistaken. Why was Canon Paul at this meeting? Why was he invited if he were not considered? Why did he speak at this meeting? The Minister might wish to reply to me, on this point, but so far as I am concerned I have no answer other than the following: "The Reverend Paul was well considered by the Officers of the Indian Department and that consideration seems to be quite evident in other spheres.

Why did not the Agent at Leask proceed to the election of the Counsellor on the Reserve on the 15th day of May last without following the provisions of the Indian Act? This meeting was called without proper notice and 10 of the Indians were absent. The Catholic Indian was seeking election was himself absent and the Agent proceeded, with the election because he wanted a certain one elected and that one was an Anglican. I am not opposed to the Candidate thus elected and accepted by the Indian Department, and that this particular Indian has always given me consideration but the election is illegal. An Indian and an Anglican protested at the time and said, "It is not fair you choose a time that so and so is away to make this election. I know that if he were here he would get all the votes." On two occasions the Agent refused to proceed with the election as he knew that this man would get in. In view of these facts it is difficult for me to remove from my mind the words in the Minister's letter, in view of the fact which I have set out, "to remove from Father Paquette's mind any mistaken impression he may be entertaining."

All I ask you is to give to the Catholic Order what they deserve, in which case I will be satisfied and I will not lose any time to vindicate certain matters to which the Catholics have a right on this Reserve."

The Catholic Indians, according to the report of the Minister, is four day schools, attended by 86 pupils. Here we have 24 pupils, on the school register, and we have an average of 18.5 for attendance. The Department cannot complain, the attendance is good. No child of Metis, White or Indian from the other Reserves come to this School. On the other hand in the Anglican school they have six or seven children only as I am informed by the Farm Instructor. In addition to this, there are two or three Indian Children that do not belong to that Reserve and in addition to this, there are some children three or four years old, attending school in spite of the fact that Indian schools restricted them to six or seven years of age.

I wish to thank you for all you have done for me, I know that I have given you a lot of work and inconvenience.

"G.E. PAQUETTE"

P.S. You would be well to bring to the attention of the Minister the anomaly in the election procedure, in order that these abuses will not be repeated.

Bien cher monsieur,

L'inspecteur de Regina, Mr Christianson, fut ici avant-hier. Comme je n'étais pas ici, il alla voir le maître d'école, Mr Bonneau, au sujet de la maison que le département indien a l'intention de construire. Il fut décidé de lui en bâtir un petit "cottage" de 16 pieds par 20 pieds. Ce sera sans doute suffisant pour le maître actuel, mais le jour qu'il quittera l'emploi de maître d'école, le sera-t-il pour son successeur. Mr Bonneau s'est permis de lui dire qu'il ne sera pas toujours ici, ce à quoi Mr Christianson lui a répondu que si le cottage serait trop petit, le département donnerait ce cottage aux Indiens et en construirait un autre. Je prévois que les mêmes difficultés seront à recommencer. Pourquoi pas bâtir quelques pieds plus grands et ce sera fini une fois pour tout.

Maintenant le ministre dans sa lettre du 31 dernier affirme que "certain figures quoted by Father Paquette in his communication are wholly at variance with our records". Le ministre devrait bien distinguer entre "enrolment" et "attendance at school" dont je veux parler. S'il y a 21 qui sont inscrits comme allant à l'école, je sais qu'il n'y a six ou sept qui fréquentent l'école. J'espère qu'il me demandera d'autres explications.

En outre le ministre trouve que c'est difficile de se convaincre lui-même "that any good purpose can be served by entering into a lengthy discussion with Father Paquette in respect to the administration of the anglican and Roman Catholic indian day school on the Big River Reserve... C'est bien simple qu'on m'accorde à ce que les catholiques ont droit et je leur laisserai la paix. Vous pouvez vous en rendre compte par les plaintes que je vous ai fait parvenir que mes plaintes étaient fondées.

TRANSLATION:

August 22, 1941.

Mr. H.R. Fleming, M.D.
Humbolt, Sask.

Dear Sir,

The Inspector from Regina, Mr. Christianson, was here the day before yesterday. As I was absent, he called on Mr. Bonneau, the teacher, to talk about the house that the Indians Affairs intends building. They decided to build a small cottage, 16 by 20 feet. It will be sufficient for the teacher they have now, but this one leaves, will it be large enough for the one who will take his place? Mr. Bonneau took the liberty of telling him that he would not remain there always, and Mr. Christianson, answered that if the cottage was then found to be too small, that the Department would give it to the Indians and build another one instead. I see that the same difficulties lie ahead of us for the future. Why not build on a larger scale and the work will be done once for all?

Now the minister in his letter of the 31st of last month states that "certain figures quoted by Father Paquette in his communication are wholly at variance with our records". The minister should make the distinction between "enrolment" and "attendance at school", which I mentioned. If 21 pupils are entered as going to school, I am aware that only six or seven attend school. I hope that he will ask me more details.

The Minister thinks that it is hard to convince oneself "that any good purpose can be served by entering into a lengthy discussion with Father Paquette in respect to the administration of the Anglican and Roman Catholic Indian day school on the Big River Reserve." That is a simple matter: Let them grant us what the Catholics are entitled to and I will
leave them alone. You can see for yourself that the complaints I have made are well founded.

I thank you very much and beg to remain,

Yours very truly,

(Signed) G.G.Paquette, O.M.I.

P.S. The Minister's answer was known long before your letter came, for the Indian Agent at Leash communicated it to Father Beaudry, who spoke about it to my superior, expecting that I would let the matter drop and that I would not write any more against the Leash Agent. Father Beaudry's steps were of no avail. They know that they are in the wrong and they use indirect means in order to succeed. The Regina Inspector has told the school teacher "That I was right" about the teacher's house or room. Good-bye and thank you.

G.E.Paquette,O.M.I.

Shell River P.O., Sask.

Dear Mr. Pratt:

Re: Indian Mission Day School,
Whitefish Reserve.

The Sisters of Providence at Prud'homme, Sask., have been engaged to teach the Indians at this point. I have a letter from one of the Sisters, saying that there is a little house for the teachers, but that there is no furniture.

They are, I believe, sending three Sisters there, and they wanted to know if I could find out if it would be possible to get some simple furnishings for this teacherage.

This does not seem like a difficult request. Perhaps you would be good enough to let me know about this.

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I am today in receipt of a letter from the Reverend Mother St. Victor, Prud'homme, Sask. You will remember you phoned me about this, and I was not sure of the information, so I got in touch with the Sisters by air mail, and that told me that this was the Big River Reserve, and that Father Paquette was the priest.

I think they are very fortunate in being able to get the Sisters to go up there and teach at the Reserve, and the Department of Indian Affairs should make it as comfortable as possible for them. Their wants will not be very much, but they should have their house properly furnished, and have good sleeping accommodation. It may take $200 or $300, but that is not very much when you consider the wonderful work they will do, and the service they will render at that point.

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Dr. H.R. Fleming, M.P.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 7th instant and note with interest the information supplied therein.

May I point out that the criticism to which I referred on August 22nd was not directed against the Department for supplying furnishings to the R. C. School on the Big River Reserve. The Government, in my experience, is seldom, if ever, criticized for the expenditure of money. The criticism was directed against us for what was alleged to be discrimination on your part, not for furnishing the teacher's residence at the Big River R. C. School, but for your refusal from time to time to purchase furniture for teachers' residences operated by other churches. It was alleged also that in the employment of men certain favours were shown. However, the critic promised to submit the whole matter to the Director in writing, and I do not know that any good purpose can be served by an interchange of correspondence on the subject at this time.

Yours truly,

To the Honorable Minister of Natural Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario

Dear Sir,

I came here to teach last October. Two Sisters stay with me and help in the arduous task of civilizing the little Indians.

When the Indian Agent, Mr. Davis came to see us last fall, he found that our residence was too small for three persons. Mr. Prince came later on and passed the same remark. Both said they would apply to you for having an addition built and make our house more hygienic.
Dear Sir, I come to beg the same favour of you. Our little house is well built, well furnished, for which we are very grateful, but it is really too small and our health will suffer from it.

Therefore, we'll be very thankful if you are kind enough to see that an addition be built to our residence as soon as possible.

Thanking you in anticipation,

I remain, Dear Sir,

Yours very gratefully and respectfully,

Sister Cecilia of Jesus.
Ottawa, April 1, 1943.

Reverend and dear Mother:

I have your letter of the 25th ultimo, enclosing a communication from the teacher of the Big River R.C. Indian Day School, in which she requests that the teachers' residence be enlarged.

Due to present conditions, our funds are so limited that I cannot hold out any definite hope that we will be able to enlarge the teachers' residence at the Big River School. Besides, many materials are extremely difficult, if not impossible, to secure. However, we are writing the Indian Agent about the matter and it will receive further consideration.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,

I am enclosing herewith a letter from Reverend Mother St. Victor giving the dimensions of the teacherage.

I wish to inform you that I visited the Roman Catholic Day School at Big River and the day I was there there were 23 children in the classroom. As you know, there are three Sisters in attendance there and I believe they are doing splendid work because I noticed quite a change to what it was before they took over.

These Sisters brought to my attention that they had no place to keep food because they have no refrigerator or anything of that type and of course they have no ice. What they wanted was to have a little porch built on the outside with a few shelves in it so that they could keep their perishable food supplies on this porch.

As there was an opportunity of getting Adam Ahenskew, who built this in the first place, in about a week's time I told the Agent to go ahead with it. I cannot give you the cost but I do not think the work and labour would amount to over $60.00 or somewhere in that neighborhood. I instructed the Agent to voucher for the material and labour on two separate vouchers. If, however, you think otherwise if you will let me know by return mail this can be cancelled but I hope it will be allowed because it is required.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I wish to bring to your attention that while up at the Carlton Agency I was in the R.C. Day School on the Big River Reserve. The Sister Superior there informed me they were getting $70.00 a year for a mid-day meal but this was not sufficient for the number of children they have going to school and she requested that this be raised to $85.00 for the coming year.

I would ask that the amount be raised to the latter figure as I think the Sister Superior was very reasonable in her request.

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa, July 7, 1944.

Mr. M. Christianson, General Supt. of Indian Agencies,
Dominion Public Building, Regina, Sask.

I desire to refer to your letter of the 24th ultimo, with reference to the amount allowed for the purchase of supplies for midday meal purposes at the Big River R.C. School.

Very careful consideration has been given to your suggestion, but I regret that we cannot see our way clear to approve any increase. We are prepared to allow this school, for the academic year 1944-45, the same amount as last year, viz.: $70.00.

I may add that this school will receive biscuits which are being manufactured from a very special recipe, prepared by the Acting Superintendent of Medical Services in conjunction with the officials of the Department of Agriculture and others. These biscuits are costing considerably more than we have been accustomed to paying, but we feel that their quality justifies us in making the increased expenditure. Before the biscuits are delivered, we expect to issue a circular letter to all schools receiving them, pointing out the necessity for distributing them as carefully as possible.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Leask, Sask.,

Mr. E. S. Jones, Indian Agent, Leask, Sask.

It has been brought to our attention that the chimney at the Big River R.C. Indian Day School requires repairs. Please let me know what repairs are required and the approximate cost of the material and labour.

We have been advised also that the amount allowed for midday meal supplies at this school was insufficient. In a letter written to Mr. Christianson on July 7, 1944, we authorized $70.00, and your voucher No. 645 of February 15, 1945, covered the expenditures incurred to that amount. It has been decided to allow an additional $15.00 for midday meal supplies for the balance of the current academic year. This will make a total of $85.00, which is the amount previously requested by the teacher.

It should be definitely understood by the Reverend Sisters and any other parties interested in this school that in allowing an amount of $85.00 for midday meal supplies for the current academic year the Department is making a special concession and that this amount is not to form a precedent for future years. As you know, we have supplied a considerable quantity of biscuits, and in view of the family allowances coming into effect this fall, we will have to review our whole policy regarding the serving of midday meals at Indian day schools.

It is not our intention to totally dispense with the serving of midday lunch, but, as stated above, we intend to review the whole matter in September.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

AIR MAIL

Mr. J. Bryce, Acting Indian Agent, Leask, Sask.,

I have your letter of the 16th instant, enclosing requisition covering expenditures in connection with the building of a chimney at the Big River R.C. Day School.

Please let me know the name and address of the firm from whom you secured the quotation for the material as submitted.

When forwarding quotations on requisitions you should always state the name and address of the firm from whom they were obtained.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

In a letter which Mr. Christianson wrote to the Department dated July 6th, 1941, File #303-11A, reference is made to the difficulty with the chimney of the classroom building at the Big River R.C. Day School. This chimney smokes badly as there seems to be no draft in it. Some efforts have been made to correct the difficulty but I do not think it can be corrected without dismantling and rebuilding the chimney off the inside of the building.

The chimney is of single-ply brick and is built on the outside of the wall on the north end of the building. In cold weather, and particularly on days when there is a north wind the chimney remains so cold that it cannot possibly have a good draft. I did not measure its length but would estimate it to be about 30 ft. The smoke pipe passes from the furnace through the concrete wall of the basement into the chimney. At this point there is naturally a considerable chilling of the air before the smoke pipe enters the chimney at all.

I have asked Mr. Bryce, Acting Indian Agent of the Carlton Agency, to submit a requisition through this office for the reconstruction of the chimney and I shall forward it with my recommendation as soon as it is received.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Mother Superior of the Big River R.C. Day School has requested a further $35.00 be authorized to purchase supplies for the noon lunches for the children attending the above school. Mother Superior's letter reads in part as follows:

"Unless you help us we will not be able to serve a real day lunch to the pupils very much longer."

Last fall the sum of $65.00 was authorized for the purchase of supplies for the noon day lunches at this school.

Mr. Hancock, teacher of the Ahtahkakoops Day School Sandy Lake Reserve has requested an additional sum of $30.00 be authorized for the purpose of purchasing further supplies for noon day meals for the pupils attending his school.

My policy in connection with noon day meals since the start of Family Allowances has been to encourage the parents to contribute towards the supplies, such as to contribute meat when game is killed also garden produce.

Last year garden crops were badly frozen on the above reserves. This winter, too, there has been a closed season on elk and moose. These facts together with the hard winter we have experienced makes the above requests seem justified.

E. S. Jones,
Indian Agent.

ESJ/ae
Ottawa, March 10th, 1947.

Mr. E.S. Jones, Indian Agent,
Leask, Saskatchewan.

In view of the information contained in your letter of the 4th instant, it has been decided to allow an additional amount of $33.00 for the current academic year for supplies for mid-day meal purposes at the Big River R.C. School and an amount of $30.00 for additional supplies for the same purpose at the Ahtahkakoops Indian Day School. You should inform the teachers of both of these schools that this is a special grant that has been made owing to the information supplied in the last paragraph of your letter and is not to form a precedent for future years.

The Department agrees with the action that you have taken as outlined in the second last paragraph of your letter. It is our policy to continue in assisting in supplying funds for mid-day meal purposes but it is not our intention to increase the amount allowed in previous years. We feel that in view of the payment of family allowances it is reasonable to suppose that the children should be better fed and that the parents should be in a better position to give their children some food to take to school for their mid-day lunch.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Regina, May 31st, 1947.

E. S. Jones, Esq., Indian Agent, LEASK, Saskatchewan.

With further reference to the matter of the floor in the basement of the R.C. Indian Day School at the Big River Reserve while visiting the St. Philip's Indian Residential School I find a kind of floor finish which I believe to be satisfactory to the Reverend Sister Superior at the Big River Indian Day School.

This material is called "Flintmix". It is mixed with coarse sand or fine gravel and laid on top of the concrete floor. It can be smoothed and levelled and has a soft feeling underfoot. It is being used on the floor of the boys' playroom at the St. Philip's School and seems to stand a lot of wear.

I was warned by the Reverend Principal, Father Tetrault, that paint or any material which contains turpentine cannot be used on this floor as it seems to destroy its texture. He showed me some spots where they had attempted to use paint. I mention this because the Sister Superior will have to be advised that the floor will be practically black and will have to remain so. If she is not satisfied with this I do not know of any other type of floor finish to advise.

If the Reverend Sister Superior agrees to this type of floor finish you could get information as to the cost, etc. from Marshall Wells and submit a requisition through this office for the quantity required. In calculating the quantity Father Tetrault has used a thickness of from 2" to 4" in levelling off the floor and he says he thinks it should not be less than 2" in order to take advantage of the feeling of softness underfoot.

J. P. B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

To Mr. E.S. Jones,
Indian Agent,

Dear Sir:

I thank you Mr. Jones, and I also thank sincerely Mr. Ostrander for the interest shown in the project of repairing the floor of our school basement. We appreciate much the trouble to undertake this rather difficult enterprise. But although we most desire to have this floor renewed, we do not wish it changed unless a sewer is placed.

We even ask more as it may be more convenient to go through it while work is going on than to look for it after it is completely done. This, we wish to have the water system (running water) installed if not at the teacherage, at least at the school.

We feel that once the new floor will be given it will be quite impossible to obtain either the sewer and the running water.

Both Mr. Ostrander and you, Mr. Jones, found these modern accommodations necessary, when you visited the school and discussed the problem together.

We do not wish to have the basement floor repaired just for a matter of appeasement but we believe these modern accommodations essential.

We are now at Prudhomme for our annual retreat and expect to be here until the end of the month.

Please accept our respect, we are yours very thankful.

Sister Superior and
Sister St. Victorien, teacher.

Mr. N.J. McLeod,

Big River R.C. Indian Day School

We have now received Mr. Provincial Inspector Amundrud's report on the above school. In his general comment he states as follows:

"From money won as prizes for work exhibited at the Prince Albert fair last summer a full set of rhythm band instruments has been secured. I was rather impressed with the quality of performance with these instruments and also with the fact that every child took part. Considerable time is now being spent in learning Christmas songs also. This is commendable, although I did feel since the learning of English presents sufficient difficulty, that the learning of songs in Latin is unnecessarily burdensome.

Pupils in the higher grades read sufficiently well to understand and do problems from their texts. Reading in the primary grades tends to be word-saying, not too closely associated with the meaning since English is heard and spoken only within the classroom. If the obstacles are not too great, I would suggest that English rather than Cree be the language of the playground also.

The schoolhouse is as usual very clean and well kept.

The furnace smokes too readily and should be repaired.

In order to free the one cloakroom for its intended use I would suggest the building of storage cupboards across the back of the classroom."
Would you please discuss with Sister Marie Ladislas the possibility of having the Indian children use English on the playgrounds rather than Cree. We realize only too well the difficulty involved in this but would appreciate a redoubling of her efforts to have English spoken. It is presumed that we will be hearing from you with regard to the furnace. Would it be possible to have a tender obtained for the installation of the storage cupboards required, or would you suggest the purchase of an unpainted cupboard from Eaton's or Simpson's?

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

I am returning herewith sketch and quotation in connection with the enlarging of the teacherage at the Big River R.C. Indian Day School, referred to in Department letter of the 11th instant, File 629-5 (E.I.).

I see little to criticise in the suggested plan for enlarging this building, or in the tender price. However, I believe it is a matter which should be dealt with in the first instance through Mr. N.J. McLeod, the Indian Superintendent in charge of that particular reserve. Please be assured that I do not make this statement because of any objection to being by-passed in the matter. However, in view of the fact that it will be Mr. McLeod's duty to see that a suitable building results, neither he nor I should be asked to give blanket approval to this suggestion without a careful examination of the present building and the foundation.

I would therefore recommend that no further action be taken to prepare a blue-print or anything else until Mr. McLeod has had the opportunity, after the snow has gone, to properly examine the present building.

It has been my opinion that the present teacherage was much too small, and I have been doubtful about the wisdom of adding further to it. However, as I say, I see little to criticise in the sketch presented, and certainly we cannot build a new building which will supply accommodation equal to that to be provided by this addition to the old building at any figure near $3400.00 (including the cost of paint). To erect a new building to provide equal accommodation will cost at least $7500.00.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

With reference to Department letter of the 14th instant, File 629-5 (E), addressed to Superintendent N.J. McLeod, regarding the Big River R.C. Indian Day School, I am enclosing herewith letter of Indian Superintendent McLeod, of the Duck Lake Agency, on the subject of increasing classroom accommodation for that school.

I am inclined to agree with Mr. McLeod's attitude as shown in his letter, for the reason that although the one classroom in the R.C. day school is usually filled, the classroom in the Anglican Day School, on the same reserve, is not filled. Actually, what is happening is that a number of the Indians of that band who have formerly been considered Anglicans are gradually switching to the R.C. faith, and I am of the opinion that eventually the number of Anglicans on that reserve will be so few that the Anglican Church will decide to withdraw from the picture. In that case the building now used for the Anglican Church Day School will be available for the R.C. Day School.

I do not think it advisable at this time to start a controversy between the two churches by adding a classroom to the R.C. Day School, but I am in favour of building a suitable teacherage, and I believe that for the present the Department should decide to proceed with enlarging the present teacherage as referred to in Department letter of the 11th of February, 1949, File 629-5 (E.1), and my reply dated February 16th, 1949, File 314-305-11A (109).

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.
Duck Lake, Sask., March 16th, 1949.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Reference is made to your Airmail letter dated
March 14th, your file 629-5 (E) regarding additions to the
Classroom at the R.C. Indian Day School on the Big River
Indian Reserve.

The situation on this particular Indian Reserve
calls for very careful consideration before making any
definite commitments, as you are aware we now have two
Indian Day Schools in operation on this particular Indian
Reserve, one run under the R.C. Mission and the other under
the Anglican Mission, both schools are located one and one
half miles apart and the buildings are identical in size and
structure and immediately any additions or alterations are
made to one school then you may rest assured that the other
mission will immediately demand that its buildings at the
other setup receive the same treatment in regards to additions
etc and if this is not done then we will be accused as showing
favouritism and this can lead to a large amount of unnecessary
work and correspondence, while I quite agree that the classroom
operated under the R.C. Mission is crowded and should be enlarged
but possibilities of the future would indicate that in say
five years, we would find that the Anglican mission will be
closed due to low membership amongst Big River Band, which
would then mean that we would be confronted with a vacant class
room.

Personally I would suggest that we leave matters as they
are for the present and I believe that we will find that the
present classrooms on the Big River Indian Reserve are sufficient
to accommodate all Indian pupils for many years to come without
going to the expense of making any further additions to either
day school at the present time. It is also quite possible that
the overcrowding at the R.C. School can be taken care of by sending
a few children into the Duck Lake School commencing with the
September 1949 term.

On my next visit to Big River Indian Reserve I will
discuss this matter fully with the Missionary in charge
with a view towards arriving at a working solution to the
problem confronting our Branch at this particular Indian
Day School. When a solution has been arrived at a full report
will be submitted.

N. J. McLeod,
Superintendent, Indian Agency.
Ottawa, April 11, 1949.

With reference to your letter dated May 12th, your file 629-5 (E.1) regarding additions to the class room at the R.C. Indian Day School on the Big River Indian Reserve.

On my recent visit to this particular day school I discussed with the missionary in charge a plan whereby additions could be made of a temporary nature that would accommodate the increased pupilage for a period of three or four years.

We decided that a suitable class room could be set up in the basement of the present building by eliminating the kitchen now installed therein. It is estimated that the costs in connection with converting the basement would amount to approximately $1000.00 covering costs of new desks, blackboards and either installing a wood floor over cement floor of basement or covering cement floor with linoleum. The additional class room will also entail salary of teacher. Living accommodations will be ample for an additional teacher immediately present additions to the teacher's residence is completed.

Should your office consider this arrangement satisfactory I would recommend that authority be given to have the contractors Messrs. Bonneau and Tremblay who are now working on the addition to the teacher's residence, employed to make the necessary alterations in the basement of the school and when it has been decided upon as to the proper manner to prepare the basement floor materials could be secured from local approved source.

Requisition for school supplies, desks, blackboards, etc will be forwarded immediately this proposal meets with your approval.

Personally I believe this proposal will take care of the anticipated increase in attendance at this particular day school for a few years at a minimum cost without causing any conflict or ill will arising between the Missionary services now on Big River Indian Reserve.

N.J. McLeod

He also states that sums were put aside in this year's budget for an annex to the school, and is wondering why this has not been done.

Dear Mr. Bertrand:

Further to my letter of August 15, with respect to the Big River Indian Day School, I am providing you with the information requested. Since Father Paquette's letter of June 11, we have carried out the following installations and repairs at this school:

(a) authorized the purchase of the materials and labour required to convert the basement room into an extra classroom, as recommended,

(b) purchased approximately $250.00 worth of paint for the painting of the exterior of this school,

(c) ordered 17 pupils' desks, one teacher's desk and one teacher's chair, with an approximate value of $400.00, for this extra classroom,

(d) requested the Departmental Purchasing Agent to secure tenders on the installation of a new coal and wood furnace with an approximate cost of $350.00,

(e) authorized an expenditure of $201.00 for material and labour for the erection of a fence around this school.

In view of our action as indicated above, we feel that Father Paquette should have little complaint concerning
the efforts of the Department to increase the efficiency of the Big River R.C. Indian Day School. In fact, our Indian Superintendent at Desk Lake, Saskatchewan, reported that he had discussed the above changes with this Missionary early in July and we therefore presume that Father Faquette is now satisfied.

Very sincerely yours,

J. G. Levy,

Pour faire suite à votre lettre du 15 août concernant l'externat indien de Big River, voici les renseignements que vous avez demandés. Depuis la réception de la lettre du Rév. Père Paquette en date du 11 juin, nous avons effectué les installations et les réparations suivantes à cette école:

(a) nous avons autorisé l'achat de matériaux et l'emploi de main-d'œuvre nécessaires pour transformer le sous-sol en une salle de classe additionnelle, comme on l'avait recommandé,

(b) nous avons acheté la peinture d'une valeur approximative de $250 pour peindre l'extérieur de l'école,

(c) nous avons commandé 17 pupitres d'élèves, un pupitre et une chaise de professeur, évalués à environ $400, pour cette salle de classe additionnelle,

(d) nous avons donné instructions au pourvoyeur de notre ministère de demander des soumissions pour l'installation d'un nouveau calorifère au charbon et au bois, d'une valeur approximative de $350,

(e) nous avons autorisé une dépense de $201 destinée à couvrir le matériel et la main-d'œuvre requis pour l'érection d'une clôture autour de l'école.

Etant donné les mesures susdites que nous avons prises, nous croyons que le Rév. Père Paquette devrait avoir bien peu à se plaindre des efforts de notre ministère pour augmenter l'efficacité de l'externat catholique indien de Big-River. Au fait, notre surintendant des Indiens à Duck-Lake, Saskatchewan,
rapporte qu'il a discuté avec ce missionnaire, au début de juillet, les changements susmentionnés, et nous supposons que le Rév. Père Paquette est maintenant satisfait.

Bien à vous,

J.G. Levy,
Secrétaire particulier.

Reference is made to your letter dated October 27th your file 629-5 (El) commenting on the contents of a letter forwarded by Reverend Father Paquette, OMI, R.C. Missionary, Big River Indian Reserve from the wording of your letter I presume Father Paquette's letter reached your office through the usual channels.

Please refer to the contents of my letter addressed to Indian Affairs Branch and dated July 9th, 1949, our file 1024-15-118 (109) setting out therein the agreement reached with Rev. Father Paquette for additions to Big River R.C. Indian Day School Classroom, the contents of this particular letter explains exactly the working agreement in which Rev. Father Paquette concurred.

The writer submitted the proposal to your office for your authorization, your letter dated August 15th, file 629-5 (El) authorized an expenditure of $67.25 for materials and $60.00 for labour, which was expended and the work completed under supervision of Assistant, Indian Agency, Mr. H. A. Jove and Rev. Father Paquette. Messrs Bonneau and Tremblay were engaged to do the work in connection with alterations and repairs to the basement floor, install blackboards etc.

You will note by the contents of my letter dated July 9th that an agreement was reached whereby the Missionary (Rev. Father Paquette) agreed to the proposal of eliminating the kitchen in the basement and installing therein a class room.
On my next visit to Big River Indian Reserve following engagement of carpenters, I found that the work had been completed, however, under instructions of the Rev. Father Paquette, a complete change had been made from our original plan and instead of removing the kitchen as agreed upon previously the kitchen was retained and only a small portion of the basement set aside for a class room, space sufficient to accommodate 15 pupils, I questioned Rev. Father Paquette in regards to changes made under his authorization and was advised by the Rev. Father, that he had decided not to eliminate the kitchen and dining room, as he considered it would be necessary for the teachers to furnish the pupils with a full course hot dinner, in attendance at the R.C. School. On being questioned as to who would furnish supplies for a full course dinner, I was advised by the Mother Superior that this would be done from the source of vegetables they had produced in school gardens plus supplies from our Branch and further supplies from their own resources.

To my mind any complaint that the Rev. Father Paquette has now to make is the results of his own interference with our original plan for altering the basement of the Big River R.C. Day School and he was advised that the changes he had made without any authorization would never prove satisfactory.

We must however also bear in mind that alterations to the basement in question in an expenditure of only $127.50 could not be considered of a permanent nature and with all respects to the Missionary, Rev. Father Paquette, the installing of a class room in the basement of the day school in question was not made with any intentions of becoming a permanent set up, we merely endeavoured to eliminate over crowding in the R.C. Indian Day School Class room until such time as an addition to the main building could be placed in our estimates.
You will note that the amount of $5000.00 is shown in our 1950-51 estimates for erection of an addition to the R.C. Indian Day School, Big River Indian Reserve.

Might I go so far as to state that the letter forwarded to your office was written by the Rev. Father Paquette to some of his friends with the view of impressing upon them the importance of having our estimates put through in order to have finances available for the addition to the Big River R.C. Indian Day School. I believe you will find this statement to be correct, as I cannot understand why the Rev. Father would or could try to place the blame for the class room being placed in the basement of this particular school, especially in view of the fact that it was placed therein at his own request and under his supervision.

I might also mention that when the original plans were made for placing the class room where it is now located, the Sisters in charge of the school were absent and again may I presume that on their return pressure was brought to bear upon the Rev. Father by the teachers to retain the dining room facilities.

Please excuse the lengthy report, however, I feel all angles of the matter should receive careful explanation and consideration.

N.J. McLEOD
SUPERINTENDENT, INDIAN AGENCY

"Re: Onion Lake Indian Day School— I visited the C. of E. Due to the disastrous fire which occurred there some time ago it left this group of Indians without an adequate school. Mr. Mullans has taken one of the old granaries and through his ingenuity and improvisations he has made the building into a school that is meeting the requirements for the present. Some expenditures will have to be made on this book to make the building satisfactory. Too much praise cannot be given Mr. Mullans for the way in which he has made this old building workable. With reference to Department letter of the 6th ultimo, file No. 113-1-1, I am enclosing herewith requisitions for labour and material for preparing the Roman Catholic Chapel building at the White Bear Reserve for a day school.

The expenditure is in connection with the erection of two outside toilets, putting in extra windows in the classroom building where needed, and the erection of a cupboard and bookcase in the building, also storm windows, sash, and storm doors.

In addition to the expenditure in connection with the building itself, authority will be necessary for $100.00 for fuel for the term, $5.00 per teaching month for janitor fees, and $5.00 per teaching month for hauling water. The Church authorities are not asking any rent for the use of the building but feel that the sum of $10.00 should be paid to cover the cost of fire insurance.

Reverend Father G. Laviolette, the Missionary, has secured the services of a suitable teacher, a single man who will board with Mr. J.R. Morrison, the Farming Instructor of that reserve, for the remainder of this term. As a married man and wife would be more suitable as a permanent appointment other arrangements might have to be made before the next term starts in September, 1946, and the erection of a small teacherage might be necessary. The present expenditures which I am recommending are in order to make temporary arrangements to open the school at the earliest possible date.

A requisition for the school supplies is being forwarded by Mr. W.J.D. Kerley, Indian Agent, Crooked Lake Agency, direct to the Department at an early date.

When the school is re-opened there are twenty-five pupils ready for immediate entrance and perhaps over thirty in the future.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Will you kindly give us authority to purchase food supplies for the two Day Schools on White Bear Reserve. While our 1947-48 Estimates provided a total of $135.00, owing to increased cost of food supplies I would recommend that this be increased to the following amounts:

White Bear Day School $100.00

W.J.D. Kerley, Indian Agent.
Ottawa, December 10, 1947.

Mr. W.J.D. Kerley, Indian Agent,
Broadview, Saskatchewan.

We have your letter of the 4th instant requesting us to increase the amounts allowed for mid day meals at the two schools in your Agency.

The Department has no funds available for increasing the amount and consequently we will only be able to allow for the current academic year the same amount as last year, namely $75. for the White Bear School and $80. at the St. Francis School.

In view of the payment of Family Allowances the Department feels that the Indians should be in a better position financially to provide additional food for their children and even give them some lunch to bring to school with them. We are not reducing any of the amounts we previously allowed for mid day meal purposes but it is not our intention to increase them.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT funds are provided in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1949-50, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, for the construction of a one-room Indian Day School and teacher's residence to replace the present St. Francis R.C. Indian Day School in the Crooked Lake Indian Agency, Province of Saskatchewan;

THAT every endeavour has been made to obtain quotations from various firms for the materials required for the building;

THAT the only complete tender received by the Departmental Purchasing Agent has been from Mills and Sons, Carlyle, Saskatchewan. They offer to supply the materials required with the exception of the paint and lower priced items of hardware, at a cost of $5,742.80, f.o.b. Carlyle, Saskatchewan.

THAT the Purchasing Agent considers the price quoted to be fair and reasonable.

THAT it is essential that these materials be purchased at the earliest possible date in order to proceed with the erection of the school.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for the acceptance of the tender of Mills and Sons, Carlyle, Saskatchewan, to supply the materials on which they have quoted at a price of $5,742.80, f.o.b. Carlyle, Saskatchewan, which due to contingencies will involve an expenditure of approximately $6,500.00.

Respectfully submitted,

PP/ST

Sir:

I have the honour to report that when at the Valley River Indian Reserve, No 624 I visited the school that has been in operation on that Reserve under the auspices of the Episcopalian Church, and wholly maintained by them for the past year off and on.

Dear Sir,

I venture to call your attention to an important matter in connection with Indian work in the district of which I have charge. I refer to the Valley River Reservation, on which decide, as you may be aware about 87 Indians.

The great need— the large number of children—the willingness, not to say anxiety, of these Indians to have their children educated appealed to us so strongly that without waiting to pass through the usual formalities, we placed a competent teacher among them about 18 months ago. To do so, it became necessary to erect suitable buildings, the expense of which including allowance for teacher for the 18 months above named amounts to the sum of $576.95.

I need not remind you that we cannot afford to take this sum from funds so badly needed for sustaining the Gospel among the heathen, nor need I call your attention to the fact that the work done at the above school in the time specified has met with the approval and been carried out to the satisfaction of your...
Mr. Markele, who visited the school from time to time.

Writing on behalf of the authorities of the church we would like you to take the necessary steps to have the above sum of $576.25 refunded us at an early date.

The Sup't of Indian Missions Archdeacon Phin has just returned from a visit to the mission and reports most favorably of the progress the children have made during the short time the school has been in operation.

It is felt however that the time has come when the financial responsibility of this school should rest with the Department.

I would therefore ask you kindly make the necessary arrangements for taking over the school, appointing a teacher, furnishing the necessary school materials, biscuits etc., so that this very promising school may receive all the encouragement and help it deserves from the Dept. Perhaps I should inform you that the average attendance for the winter ending 30th Sept. was 11.5 and when it is kept in mind that the No. of children on the Reserve of school age is only 19, the above average is promising.

I am very anxious this matter should have your earliest attention and
I should be glad if you will communicate with Archdeacon Phelan at Winnipeg that he may recommend a competent and suitable man for this important work, and also that the teacher may reach his work at the Valley River before the winter sets in.

Mr. Marble will probably have informed the Dept. of the great want and pressing the supply of medicine has been to these isolated Indians, on whose behalf we beg to thank you most sincerely, and trust that a necessary supply for the present winter will be forthcoming in good time.

Remain

Yours truly,

George Gill
MEMORANDUM for the Deputy Minister:

In regard to the application made by the Rev. Mr Gill of Russell, Manitoba, for a grant of $516.95 to reimburse the Church for the outlay made in building a schoolhouse on the Valley River Reserve, and paying the salary of a teacher.

The undersigned begs to say that this application is similar to the one lately made by the Missionary at Eagle Lake, who was informed that the Department regretted that any expenditure had been incurred with the expectation of getting the Department to recoup the Society, without first making their wants known to the Department.

No provision is made in the Estimates for the establishment of these schools and no funds are available for paying anything for buildings or equipment. The policy of the Department as lately followed is in the direction of limiting the number of day schools when possible.

There are said to be 19 children of school age on the Reserve, while in his report for '95 the Agent gives the number as 10, and judging by the attendance at other schools in the Territories it is considered to be the largest possible average that could be obtained, which would give an average cost per pupil of about $55, after adding $100 to the usual salary for repairs, equipment, school material, fuel &c.

The undersigned considers that the money could be spent to better advantage in providing for more pupils at the existing boarding schools than in the establishment of day schools where the average attendance would always be small.

19th November '96
Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 10th instant applying for a grant of $500.95 to reimburse the Church for the outlay made in building a schoolhouse on the Valley River Reserve, and in providing the salary for a teacher; and in reply I beg to say that it is regretted that the Department is not first communicated with before any expense was incurred in connection with this school, as were it disposed to sanction the establishment of a school on the Reserve, provision would have to be made in the Estimates and the money voted by Parliament for the purpose, before any authority could be given. As it is the Department regrets that it has no funds available from which the grant asked for could be paid.

I may add that the Department, owing to the extremely large and increasing outlay in connection with Industrial and Boarding schools throughout Manitoba and the Territories, is averse to increasing the number of day schools now in existence and instead of doing so, it contemplates closing some already in existence.

There are still vacancies at the Rupert's Band school, where children belonging to the Church of England could be sent.

Dear Sir:

In connection with your favor No. 145277/1 of the 26th July, concerning the nomination of a qualified teacher to succeed Miss Annie Clark at the Valley River day school, I would beg to report concerning my visit to the school and to the mission on Tuesday, August 15th.

I spent the major part of the forenoon observing, examining and inquiring into the work done in the school.

There was less in attendance, 2 boys and 3 girls, varying in age from seven to fourteen. The only trouble encountered, all with tubercular lungs. All the pupils were neatly clad and very cleanly in appearance. Some one boy all carried their book, newspapers, and stockings to the school and put them on them. The school premises inside and out were also very tidy and clean, and all school property gave evidence of careful watchfulness against injury.

The discipline was exceedingly good; the pupils being orderly, obedient and industrious.

In language and reading - in our class - all three pupils who knew no English anyway - had mastered thoroughly the first pages of the Ontario Primer. All read distinctly with the usual Indian intonation and readily. All evidenced an intelligent knowledge of the reading matter in their pages. (1) They were able to spell orally and to writing all the words in the lesson. (2) They translated the English sentence into Sanskrit. (3) They composed sentences using the new words in the lesson. Their sentence was written without any aid whatever. The following sentence was taken at random from the slates, using the words underlined:

Sir,

I beg to inform you that on 25th September last I wrote you regarding the re-opening of the Valley River School. At the time of writing I was informed by Mr. Walls that the Roman Catholic Church was willing to place a man in charge of this school, and that I was not prepared to meet with their request until I had your approval, as I felt that the missionary work on this reserve belonged to the Protestant denominations.

Since writing you however, I am in receipt of a letter from the Roman Catholic Priest, at Kamsack, in which he informs me that he wrote to Mr. Inglett, the party about whom he spoke to Mr. Walls as likely to accept the position at the Valley River School, telling him that

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
he had better make application himself for the position, but has received no reply from him.

The Reverend Father suggests that a half-breed, without any qualifications, be placed in charge of the school, temporarily. I have no hesitation in saying that this would be a great mistake and I would be the last to recommend any such move. I doubt very much if this school should be re-opened, as I am strongly of the opinion that we will never get results from Day Schools for a long time. The parents of the present day children do not take the interest in the schools that they should and the home influence and environments are so strong, that any good that is derived from the school during the day is more than offset by the time the children spend at home.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Mr. Scott,

Hon. Sir James Lougheed -

With reference to attached letter from His Grace the Archbishop of Winnipeg regarding the Valley River school, I beg to say that this school was closed on March 1st, 1928 on account of poor attendance. In the latest report from our agent dated January last it was stated that there were seven Roman Catholic and two Presbyterian children of school age on the reserve. With this number of children it will readily be seen that a successful day school could not be carried on. This school previously was undenominational and the fact that there are both Roman Catholic and Protestant children on the reserve complicates the situation somewhat.

Our experience with day schools on many of the reserves in the western provinces has been very unsatisfactory, and our policy at the present time is to educate these children so far as possible in the boarding and industrial schools. Honorable Minister:

On the radio, I hear that Parliament is in session. Because I am a resident in your constituency and because you represent the Indian Dept. I come to ask you a very special and urgent favor. I am the Indian missionary for the reserve of Valley River, Manitoba. This Indian reserve is situated between Roblin and Grandview, close to Shortdale, Manitoba. There are 25 families of Indians there and here is their plea. They absolutely want a day school on the reserve. In their names and mine, I humbly ask you to use your absolute influence to get the Government to vote a sum of $5000 dollars for this purpose. Our reasons are the following: The Indians want their children near them. Actually they are in Camperville and St. Philip's boarding schools which are approximately 125 miles away. The reserve is an ideal place for a day school, all the families are very near each other. Children would not need to walk far. There is yet another reason. The parents are so much taken about the idea of a day school, that they are taking every legitimate and illegitimate means to get it. For instance, they will encourage their children to run away from boarding schools. They even tried to influence some C.C.F. members of Parliament to get it for them. Actually they have approached some lawyers to work the matter out for them. Seeing all that, I decided to write you. I did not have time to consult their Indian Agent of Kamsack, Sask., as I should have, I understand. I would have liked to see you personally at Russell, but I was told that you were away.

Would you, therefore, do everything in your power to get the Indian Dept. to grant us this urgent request. A day school at Valley River Indian Reserve is needed, I know. A teacher would do much to maintain order on the Reserve. The Catholic teacher of the Indian school of Skownan, Manitoba, is ready to take over at Valley River. She is a Sister of Service, Patricia Fuller, who is about to quit on the Waterhen Reserve because she has too few children.

I urgently hope that you will obtain this day school for us at Valley River. At any rate, your answer will oblige me very much. I am a Catholic missionary; the Indians at Valley River are mostly Catholic and our Oblate Fathers, Principals of both the Catholic schools at Camperville and St. Philip's have urged me to appeal to you in the matter. They have difficulties with the children of Valley River precisely because they want a day school to be near their parents. We can hardly blame them, nor the parents. So it is serious and I beg you to believe that I am not talking through my hat. We want this to come through and we know that you can do everything to help us.

Trusting that you will give this matter, your complete and kind attention, I am,

Yours very humbly,

Memorandum:

MR. HOEY,

Re: Mr. Pratt's memorandum of March 18, enclosing letter from Reverend Joseph Poulette, O.M.I., requesting the erection of a day school on the Valley River Reserve.

The above mentioned school is in the Pelly Indian Agency, but the reserve itself is in the province of Manitoba. The 1944 census gives the following information:

| Membership of Band | - | 170 |
|---------------------|---|-----|
| Roman Catholic Adherents | - | 143 |
| United Church Adherents | - | 25 |
| Others | - | 2 |

Number of children between 7 and 16: 35

In Father Poulette's letter he states that 29 children from this reserve are enrolled in the Pine Creek Residential School and 5 at the St. Philip's Residential School. This makes a total of 34 children who are receiving education, and if the figures given in our 1944 census are correct, practically all the children of the Valley River Band have educational advantages.

Father Poulette estimates the cost of a school, teacher's residence and furnishings for same at $5,000.00. As you are aware, a one-room school with a teacher's residence attached has in recent years cost us between seven and eight thousand dollars. In addition, all the necessary furnishings such as desks, etc., have to be purchased.
We have requests for a very large number of day schools throughout the country, but, owing to present conditions, it will be possible to erect only a few of these this summer. In many places where schools are required no educational facilities are available at the present time. In the case of the Valley River Reserve, the children are able to attend a residential school.

Several years ago we operated a day school on the Valley River Reserve, but it was closed in 1916 and has never been re-opened.

If a day school were opened on this reserve, it would involve taking 24 children from residential schools. In the case of the Pine Creek Residential School, it would mean a loss of 29 pupils. Possibly they could recruit others to replace those from Valley River, but on the other hand, it is possible that they would be unable to do so, and in the latter event the operation of the Pine Creek Residential School would be extremely difficult from a financial standpoint.

If it is desired to operate a day school on this reserve during the academic year 1946-47, the only possible solution would be to rent a building, as we have not provided any funds in the coming year's appropriation for the erection of a new school. At the moment I am not aware if any building could be rented. To obtain this information we would have to communicate with the Indian Agent.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, March 21, 1946.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

After giving mature consideration to the project of once more building a day school on the Valley River Reserve and seeking the advice of Fathers who are in a position to form an opinion on the subject, I arrived at the conclusion that the project is untimely. Furthermore, in the event that the school was built, I hardly think we could find a teacher who could handle such a difficult situation and succeed in gaining the full confidence and securing the sincere cooperation of the Indians.

Father Poulet seems to have been moved, in presenting his request, by the conditions now prevailing in the Province of Saskatchewan and the sudden interest the politicians of that Province have shown for matters connected with the Indians generally. The issue was raised at Valley River by a politician holding views similar to those of the politicians of the neighbouring province.

Father Charles Ruest, Principal of the Pine Creek Residential School, in answer to a request from me, expressed his views on the matter as follows:

(1) Against a day school at Valley River

Formerly, there was a day school on the Valley River Reserve but, owing to a lack of cooperation from the parents and their bitter criticisms of the teachers in charge, its doors had to be closed.

The dealings our Principals and missionaries have had with these Indians for many years past tend to show that it is almost impossible to get along with them and that, whatever one may do to meet their demands, they will never be satisfied.

In view of the fact that, among the 124 children now boarding at the Pine Creek School 25 are from Valley River, the Principal is wondering whether he could reach his number if the latter were to attend a day school on their own Reserve.
There are serious grounds also to question the ability of the parents to give the children the food and clothing they require. It is rather to be expected that many of them would not be properly looked after and hence would suffer from malnutrition. Father Ruest mentions ten children in particular who either have no father, or whose father vagabonds from one place to another, or whose parents are in a condition of extreme want.

(2) In favor of a day school at Valley River

The attitude of the parents towards the Pine Creek Residential School is openly hostile. The children are aware of this and are naturally influenced by their parents. Hence the Pine Creek School is greatly hampered in its efforts in behalf of these children although some of them, at least, profit by their attendance.

On the other hand, the residence on the Reserve itself of a capable Catholic teacher who could hold sway over the Indians might help a great deal in bringing them to their senses and have a beneficial effect on parents and children alike. Unfortunately, however, the unfavorable dispositions of the parents make this hope seem very problematic.

I might add that the very motives that prompt the Valley River Indians to ask for a day school are in themselves rather an added reason for us to doubt that the venture would have any success at all.

I trust the above will throw some light on the matter and enable you to help those concerned in reaching the best decision in the circumstances.

Truly yours,

R.A. Hoey Esq., Director, Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of March 23rd, with copies of letters from Rev. Fr. Poulette to the Hon. J.A. Glen, and his answer thereto.

For various reasons I was unable to contact Rev. Fr. Poulette until last Monday at Roblin Manitoba. The matter of a Day School at Valley River Reserve was discussed fully and from every angle with the Reverend gentleman.

I might say that there is no suitable building on or near the Valley River reserve that would be suitable for school purposes, except the new Roman Catholic Church. Rev. Fr. Poulette thought that his superiors would have no objection to us using the church for this purpose provided we paid a reasonable rent and put in the necessary desks, blackboards, possibly erected a small shed for storage of church furniture and other uses.

I have since discussed this matter with the Reverend Father Provincial of this Catholic Order and he advises that we are at liberty to use the church until we build a school next year provided other obstacles are overcome.

Rev. Fr. Poulette was sure that he could on short notice secure a capable teacher that would be quite willing to start in at Valley River in September providing we had the necessary building. He had in mind Miss Fuller, who has been teaching at Shoal River Reserve in Manitoba for several years. However the Rev. Fr. Provincial points out that Miss Fuller is very poor health, which is possibly unknown to Rev. Fr. Poulette.

There used to be a day school at Valley River many years ago, and the Catholic order found that it was almost to satisfy the parents or children; complaints were many and often unwarranted according to the recollections of the Rev. Mr. Principal. Finally the school was destroyed by fire and the bone of contention was removed. The Rev. Fr. Provincial does not appear to be at all anxious to see another day school started unless we could be sure of a good man teacher for the first couple of years at least.

Mr. Dousette and the Rev. Fr. Provincial called together to discuss the matter of this school with me, and we had a round table discussion in connection with this proposed school.

Mr. Dousette advised that he already had several school vacant because he was unable to get the suitable teachers. This would appear to be the main reason why action should be deferred for the time being.

Personally I would like to see a day school on this reserve. It is very suitable for a day school as most of the children would be quite close and none more than one and a half miles from the proposed site. The right type of teacher would be a great help in improving the conduct of the younger people at least, by finding other suitable outlets for their surplus energy by directing them in wholesome pleasures and sports.

Every Indian on the reserve appears very anxious to have the Day school again, which I think could be made a success in spite of past failures. The church could be made quite suitable for our use for a year. The cost would I am sure of a new building would run to around $15,000.

The Valley River Day School at Timberton in charge of Rev. Sister Patricia, T.O.S.F. is doing very well indeed in spite of lack of space and shortage of equipment. The attendance has been exceptionally good and the children appear to be making splendid progress.

The parents are well pleased with the Day School and having their children at home daily. It is hoped that every effort will be made to have a new school constructed in 1947 to take the place of the leased Catholic Church being used for a school at the present time. It would appear advisable to erect a two room school on this Reserve.

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

Having enjoyed, for the past twenty-five years, the happy experience of the cooperation and generosity of the Indian Department, I wish at the closing of my first year at the above school, to acquaint the Department with the existing conditions regarding the school building and supplies, etc.

As the Department is already aware we are using the church as a school-room. The floor space is 22 ft x 20 ft, in it we have thirty-six separate desks, all occupied. It is necessary for me to walk the length of the room to pass from one row of desks to another. In September we are expecting ten new pupils. I have the desks in storage for them, but where to put them is a problem I am leaving, in the hope that the school building will be ready for the September term. We have not a table nor cupboard, as there is absolutely no space to put them. All reserve supplies are laying on my bed-room floor, as was also the winter dinner supplies.

The Department has questioned my request for laundry soap. As the school and towels have to be washed every week, I
do not think I asked for too much for a whole year's supply, taking into account that the women use now three cakes a week, and that the school building will be much larger, and furnished. But I did make the mistake of ordering for the whole year. Mr Agent Bryant informs me that I should requisition as needed, and that he will purchase paper towels for us. This pleases me greatly. If we could have paper cups, instead of as now, every one drinking from the one cup, I should be even more pleased.

The Department mentioned to Mr Agent Bryant, that I am seemingly indifferent to the new Indian School Bulletins, as I have not applied for any of the books. Quite the contrary is the truth. I am deeply interested in them. But while we have not even shelf space we can not avail ourselves of their benefits.

This brings me to the subject of text books. Mr Inspector Ostrander informed me that he wishes these pupils to advance to Grade eight at least. Given the necessary books at once, I can see no reason ten out of my thirteen teen age pupils should not pass. But at present they have only Arithmetics, Spellers, Children Round the World and Living in Manitoba, to study from. I asked the Department for 14 Elementary English Grammars, by MacLaurin and Campbell. I have been informed that I may have only one.

It is impossible to teach Geography, Grammar, and History, etc., orally in a school of this size. A few of the brighter ones might pass their entrance examination with this method, but not the majority, and the three divisions of Grade one could not receive the strong foundation I feel every beginner needs.
May I now refer to the more personal subject under the Indian Department's consideration, that of my teaching classification. I come very definitely under the Welfare Teaching Division.

That I am doing little Welfare work here at present is due solely to the lack of a building. At present I can only aid in their spiritual and moral welfare. I hold services on Sundays, then I take the opportunity of teaching the adults something of morality.

The Farm Instructor is also the despenser. So I have not the sick to care for. On this Reserve I would not wish it. We have three doctors at phone's call. There is nothing either interesting or satisfying for the despenser.

Now, how can I class myself as a Welfare Teacher? On my past experience and future hopes. I served three years at Berens River, and four years at Bloodvein River. Six months of each year it was impossible to connect the doctor either personally or by mail. Then I had full responsibility of the sick and injured. The winter mail took a month, and the summer mail took one week to bring me doctor's instructions. During my 17 year service at Waterhen Reserve, I sent for the doctor three times—it took 24 hours to get him, and I sent out an average of one patient a year.

I had girl's and boys clubs, Nursing and First Aid Classes for women. Encouraged and assisted the Indians in their gardens and homes, and in everything that interested them. They brought all their sorrows and troubles to me, even their sick animals. In all this I found great satisfaction and happiness. I could not have done so badly, as I have had many letters and one petition
from the Indians asking me to return to them.

I have promised Rev Father Poulette, my present superior, that I will stand by him to get this school completely organized, and to give the adults a fair opportunity to show if they wish to improve their moral and spiritual standards. We have already observed a slight improvement. At both Christmas and Easter, some Indians who had not been to the sacraments for eighteen and twenty years did so then. Under these circumstances I wish the Department to allow me to remain here for the 1947-48 term. But I am asking very frankly to be allowed to return to another isolated mission—preferably to the Kamloops B.C. Agency. I wish to serve in the beauty and warmth of B.C. I have friends there who write me of its picturesqueness and of the fine type of Indians.

Apart from the church and clubs, these Indians do not need me. They are all very nice to me, and state that they will not let me leave them. But they have the Farm Instructor all the time, The Agent and Inspector often, and the doctor every time they ask. Of course, Rev Father Poulette feels strongly that I am the only one to handle the situation at present. I think he is right. The spiritual and moral standards of these Indians are at such a low level, that, I agree with Rev Father Poulette, that a lay teacher could not do much. As a religious they know it is my work to try to straighten them up, and so, at least, listen respectfully. These Indians are wishing for a little hospital here. If I may be allowed to express my own opinion, I would suggest that the very best thing for this Reserve would be to have Sisters here to teach—in 1949 there
out to be about sixty pupils—take charge of clubs and meetings for the children and women, the church and a cottage hospital.

I do believe the Department would gain financially, and the church and Indians in spiritual and moral strength. There was much opposition to my coming here owing to the impression that the Indians are too rough. I have found all very respectful. I am sure other sisters would find the same. But I do think a lay woman would have too much attention from certain of the men, and I am inclined to think a man teacher might have too many interferences. But as I stated, all this is just my own opinion, I have not discussed it with Rev Father Poulette.

Finally, my teaching qualifications. I have no Canadian standing. I received my education at private schools in England. I was taking a preparatory medical course, when financial reverses forced my leaving school. Then came war 1914. I served as a despatch clerk, and a volunteer ambulance and signalling instructor.

I am a St John's silver medalist, and a member of the Pelman Institute of America. I have found this course most useful, especially in teaching my weak minded pupils at Waterhen Reserve, and the one poor little mentally defective boy in this school, as well as applying the teaching in so far as it is suitable for children.

When I have a pupil ready to take the entrance examination I shall take the course, by correspondence, first, to be certain that I am teaching the child in every detail as required by the province. But I have not had the means to take a course that would not be used for years, if at all. The medical studies, I have
kept up as best I could. I would very gladly pay for a course if it is possible to obtain one by correspondence.

If the Department can assure me that I shall be given another dispensary, I intend to take the St John's examination for the gold medal.

Without being conceited, I feel that my St John and Pelman Institute diplomas, along with my twenty-five years of practical medicine and minor surgery, and general Indian Reserve experience should place me in the higher salary bracket. Had I all these years held a First Class Teacher's Certificate, of what value would it have been to me compared with the diplomas I now hold and my experience. Is it quite just to keep me in the lowest classification, with the same salary as a young inexperienced girl.

I leave my classification to the Department's sense of fairness and generosity.

I beg to remain

Yours respectfully

[Signature]

Patricia T.C.S.F
Kamsack, Saskatchewan,

Re: Valley River School.

Rev. Sister Patricia has now been transferred to B.C. and I wondered if any arrangements have been made to appoint another teacher for Valley River School in order that school may re-open on September 2nd. The Indians of Valley River Reserve are very anxious to have the day school continued and I hope every effort will be made to find a suitable teacher. I discussed this matter with Rev. Fr. Poulette some time ago and he would be very pleased to have Mrs. Allbright in charge of the school if a Catholic teacher is not immediately available.
