On a recent visit to the Pelly Agency I visited the three Indian day schools therein, namely Valley River, Key's, and Cote.

I found the attendance at the Valley River Reserve was very satisfactory. There are 36 children on the roll, and the average attendance for the immediately preceding month was 93.8%. A large number of the children had not missed a day, and those who had missed, had missed only a very few days because of illness.

The attendance at the Key's and Cote Day Schools was very unsatisfactory. That of the Key's School was 70.23%, and that of the Cote School 58.95%. The Key's School, with 26 on the roll, had an average daily attendance of 18.26. The Cote School, with 44 on the roll, had an average daily attendance of 25.94. I pointed this out to Indian Agent Mr. J.L. Bryant, and the teachers concerned, and drew the attention of Mr. Bryant to the fact that Family Allowances payments should be stopped in many instances. Mr. Bryant is to immediately warn the parents that failure to greatly improve the attendance will result in loss of Family Allowances payments, and possibly prosecution. Aside from the matter of attendance I feel that very little is being accomplished at either the Cote Day School or the Key's Day School, and I do not consider the teachers concerned are giving the service which we are entitled to expect.

The teacher at the Valley River Day School, a Miss Zastre, commenced her duties this term. She is a teacher of long experience, and although her qualifications are not high I believe she is performing very satisfactory work. She is making the classroom work interesting; which, of course, accounts for the good attendance to a great degree.

J.F.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgement your letter of July 22nd. File 117-5-1 W-E-1 in connection with the transfer of Reverend Sister Patricia from Meten Indian School to the Valley River Indian School, effective September 1st, 1946.

By arrangement I met Reverend Father Poulette at Valley River Reserve last Thursday. The Church building with two living rooms attached will be fairly suitable for the school and living quarters for Reverend Sister Patricia. There is no basement in the Church and no suitable place for storage of vegetables, butter or other perishable supplies and I would recommend that a cellar 10ft. by 12ft. be excavated under the living room attached to the Church, this could be done by Indian labour. This would cost approximately $50.00. We will also have to dig pits and build two outside toilets at a cost of approximate $35.00 each.

I am attaching a requisition for necessary desks, blackboards etc. which I think could be supplied by Christie's School Supply Co., Brandon Manitoba.

I have also asked Reverend Father Poulette to get in touch with Reverend Sister Patricia as soon as possible so that she may make up a requisition for the school supplies books etc. that she will require before the school opens.

It is expected that the usual noon day lunch will be provided for the children and I would appreciate being advised the amount that may be expended for the purpose during the Academic School Term, September 1st to June 30th 1947.

Some cooking utensils, dishes, spoons, knives, forks, pails etc. will be required but these could be purchased locally as soon as Reverend Sister Patricia lets me know what she will require in this connection.

We have a large portable granary on Valley River Reserve that will not be in use this year and I plan to have this moved to the rear of the Church where it can be used for storage purposes for this year.

J. L. Bryant,
Indian Agent.

Valley River School.

I am attaching herewith a requisition for 10 more desks for Valley River school. There is an attendance of 40 pupils at the present time and there are at least another nine of school age that should be in attendance after harvest.

Rev. Sister Patricia is really getting along splendidly, she has excellent order and almost a 100% attendance. The blackboards just arrived this week and Mr Allbright expects to get them put up for her this week end.

The Sister has a pony that she is very attached to and I had a small log stable put up back of the school for this animal. I might say that water for the school has to be hauled about three hundred yards, she has a stone boat and a 40 gallon tank and the pony is used to haul the water. Mr. Alphonse Slouet
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I enclose Mr. Barville's letter about conducting and building our Indian School at Tinterton, for Valley River Indian Reserve.

They are Albert Barville and Sons, Jean and Roland, from St-Pierre Joly, Manitoba.

I do not think you can find any better Carpenters for good, quick, and efficient work. You will notice that they
have raised their price, from $1.00, and 70c for his tools, to $1.50 for himself, and $1.25 for his sons. I can't help that. The 0.50c allotted to Indian helpers seems to satisfy them, although some of them are getting 55c per hour at the mill.

My humble opinion is that they should be paid 0.75c per hour, if they work well, and I think they will. It would be only fair to help them out, while at the same time making them work for a good cause. With Banville & Sons, they are bound...
Most of lumber, shingles, could be had at the Centennial Lumber Co., a few yards away. I believe plans should be sent to me, or Mr. Albright, Farm Instructor, so as to know what is actually required as far as lumber, or other materials, are concerned. Or do, as you please; it is none of my business. But we are completely blind in trying to help you.

At any rate, the site is chosen, a very good one. We are all satisfied. But as far as water is concerned, we have tried to guess with a fellow. None of
us, is an expert at it. But we do hope water could be found near our chosen spot. Some say water can be found almost everywhere. Some others have some doubts; we leave it to you. But please advise us to the progress of your intentions.

Or should we wait patiently? Tell us your wishes or intentions, in a word, advise. That will be appreciated. Actually, we are completely alike minds.

Now here, I wish to mention one important point. It is my wish, that about six more treaty Indians, be
accepted in our new schools. So far, I have asked for this favour, without avail. Mr. Bryant, Indian Agent, has always refused me, for lack of space. In the meantime, those children are without schooling. I wish you help me at this point. Or should I write to the Minister of Indian Affairs? It is a serious problem, and I am asking this, not for doing a favour to myself or parents of these children, but for the education of some six children, which is sorely needed. One parent, at least, is ready to pay a little.
I believe it could be arranged that the Dept. of Education of Manitoba pays for them. The Indian Dept. is doing just that here, in Big Earth, where I presently am, and where you have seen me.

Now I am exhausted. But I shall appreciate your kind cooperation on all these matters.

Yours sincerely,

Rev. Joseph Poulet

Elphinstone

Manitoba

The above is my right address
to give their very maximum of work.

Now Indians have teams of horses and they can well dig out basements. But a larger pay should be allotted for Indians working with their teams. After talking with them, they all seemed to be satisfied, with 50 cts per hour for men, and an extra 50 cts for a team of horses, per hour.

Now, the only thing to decide is to be responsible and pay them fair wages, and also more. This is not for me to decide. I have given my humble opinion and that is all. You know of their wishes, at the same time.
I hope to get the Barrie's by 1st of August. Indians would like to start in June or July.

At any rate, I was at Valley River on Sunday May 28th. Mr. Allbright and I, as well as most Indians, have agreed of having the school built right at East end of sports ground, across the road from church. The teacher would then have windows facing west, having children on sport ground, right under her eyes, recess times. Some day windows must be facing East. To that, I can't say much.

DEPUTY MINISTER

Valley River Indian Day School.

Included in our Main Estimates for 1948-49 is a sum for the construction of an Indian day school at Valley River, Pelly Agency, Saskatchewan.

Mr. Doucet recently visited this reserve and was able to make contact with a foreman - carpenter and his two sons, who were willing to undertake the construction of this school. These carpenters are highly recommended by the local Missionary, Father Poulet, who writes as follows:

"I do not think you can find any better carpenters for good, quick and efficient work".

The foreman - carpenter is Mr. Albert Banville, of St. Pierre Joly, Manitoba. We would ask that he be paid at the rate of One Dollar and Fifty Cents ($1.50) per hour and that his two sons be paid at the rate of One Dollar and Twenty-five Cents ($1.25) per hour. All the rest of the labour will be Indian. Mr. Banville and his two sons will board locally at no expense to the Department.

The Departmental Purchasing Agent will be asked to buy all the necessary materials.

It is recommended that you approve the hiring of Mr. Banville as foreman - carpenter for the construction of the Valley River Indian Day School.

Re: Valley River Day School

I have for acknowledgement your letter of June 18th, together with bill of material required for this school. Blueprint plans have also been received.

This week I called to see the superintendent of the Continental Lumber Co. branch, at Timberton, Manitoba.

This Company have a mill at Timberton siding, and can supply all our requirements in spruce lumber. They also have connections with several mills in British Columbia but are very doubtful if they could supply the fir lumber that we require due to the recent serious flood situation in that Province. However, I am sure that if they are unable to obtain the fir there will be little hope of getting it anywhere else this year. This firm supply most of the local lumber yards in the district. The Superintendent would not quote a price, but intimated that as our requirements would amount to more than a car load the lumber would be supplied at wholesale prices!

They have some nails on hand at Timberton and are satisfied that they can obtain all we require. These are American nails and will cost approximately 12¢ per pound. However nails are still in very short supply and we will just have to pay the price.

The firm will quote a price on the lumber delivered at the school site as required. The school site is a little over half a mile from their planning mill.

The Indians at Valley River Reserve will be employed to deliver the stone but the gravel and sand will have to be hauled by truck. I examined three gravel pits within ten miles of Timberton but was not quite satisfied with the gravel, there is still another pit that I wish to see but due to a very heavy rainfall on Tuesday afternoon I was unable to get there. If it could be arranged I would prefer Mr. Banville to meet me at Timberton, for a few hours as soon as possible in order that we could decide on the most suitable gravel available and other matters.

The Continental Lumber Co. have a large Cat Tractor and Bulldozer with which they could excavate the basement. They will supply the outfit to us free but we pay the operators wages and gas and oil required. It is estimated the excavation could be completed in about three days. Mr. Banville may wish to have this work done after he arrives or he may prefer to have me proceed with the work now.
We have a building 14 x 12 which will be hauled to the school site for storage purpose and I have also arranged for a storage shed at Timberton siding that we can have use of to store supplies cement and other supplies until they are required at the site.

I might add that the Continental Lumber Co. in Winnipeg, have very good connections and I would suggest that they be requested to supply all the building material, lumber, bricks, clay tile pipe, weeping tile, asphalt shingles, wall board, paper etc. They would possibly have less difficulty obtaining material in short supply than we would.

Mr. Theo Sparks is the general manager and is possibly well known by Mr. Hoey, Mr. Pratt and other officials of our Department.

J. L. Bryant,
Superintendent.

P.S. Mr Albert Benwell is at present located at Fort Frances ON.
I wish to advise that the excavation for this school is almost completed.

We are also digging a well and are down 20 feet but have not yet struck water.

The cement for the foundation has arrived and is unloaded and stored near the school site.

Arrangements have been made to haul the gravel by truck. Lumber and nails for the forms for the cement work is available at Timberton, and will be delivered by the Continental Lumber Co. as we require it. This firm has not yet heard from the purchasing agent in connection with supplying the other building material.

There are three gravel pits from which gravel may be obtained and I will wait until Mr. Banville arrives before starting to haul, as I would like his opinion as to which is the most suitable. We can haul the gravel while he is erecting the forms so there will be no delay in this connection.

I understand that Mr. Banville is finishing a school at Fort Francis and that he expects to be ready to start work at Timberton the first week in August.

May I suggest that a septic tank and inside toilet and bath be installed in this school when it is being built.

J. L. Bryant,
Superintendent.

Mr. Banville arrived yesterday morning ready to start work on the Valley River Day School.

He has three carpenters with him including his two sons. I understand Mr. Banville is to be paid at the rate of $2.00 per hour but this was not stated in your letter of June 18th, 1948.

The excavation is completed and a well has been dug with a fair supply of good water at 40 feet.

The material for the forms has been purchased and we practically are assured of the supply of all material required for the cement work.

I met Mr. Sparks of the National Lumber yards Ltd. this morning at Timberton, Manitoba. I advised you that the material should be purchased through the Continental Lumber Co. but evidently the firm is now known as the National Lumber Yards Ltd. Mr. Sparks feels that his firm can supply all the building material required but points out that 3 inch hardwood flooring would have to be supplied instead of 2 inch.

Mr. Sparks advised that up to the present he had not heard from the purchasing agent in connection with the material required for this building.

Mr. Banville requests that he and his men be paid weekly but in view of Income Tax deductions etc. I hope he will agree to being paid every two weeks.

It is expected that there will be at least two months work providing we are able to get another one or two carpenters and a few handy men to assist with the rough work. It is expected that a few Indians will be employed.

I will require a further accountable advance to pay wages and would suggest $3,000.00 as the amount that may be required. It would be appreciated if this could be forwarded as soon as possible.

This morning I ordered the coal chute and we will also have to get the basement window frames within a few days as these should be put in before we run the cement. These will also be ordered at once.
Within a couple of days I will send you a copy of the orders for material that have been placed so that there will be no duplication of the order. However, I have just ordered everything that is necessary for the construction of the basement.

J. L. Bryant,
Superintendent.

Re: Valley River School.

I wired you Saturday night to advise that we had approximately 100 sacks of surplus cement at Valley River School. In case you might wish to use this elsewhere this fall. There may be close to 150 sacks but they were difficult to count as we have the hard wood flooring stored in the shed which covers most of the cement.

My experience is that cement gets very hard if kept over winter in freezing temperatures. However, if the school basement is really dry which I think it should be it could be stored there. I am advised by several dealers that it would be safer to dispose of it this fall if it is not going to be used. The cement cost us about 90 cents and will readily sell at 1.25 per sack.

We have had some delays in the construction work due to lack of material and I had to lay off three of the carpenters over a week ago. The insulation and the windows were the chief holdup. However, we got half of the insulation last week with the balance promised in a few days. The windows had to be specially made and these are promised for shipment from Winnipeg tomorrow. The insul brick siding should also arrive this week so there should be no more delays due to lack of material. It would appear now that it will be around November 15th, before the work is fully completed.

I consider Mr. Albert Banville a very competent foreman who thoroughly understands all branches of construction work, and I would recommend that you obtain his services for any other school building you may plan to build next summer. His three sons and a nephew work with him and are all good workmen.

J. L. Bryant,
Superintendent.

Re: Valley River Day School.

I am pleased to advise that the windows and doors for this school arrived at Timberton on Monday and as we now have everything that is required, good progress should now be made in completing the building.

The heating system has been supplied by the Campbell Heating Company and will be installed by Mr. Banville. I note that there were no charges included for installation by this firm, see our Voucher No. 1007.

You have advanced us $3,800.00 for payment of wages etc. and after paying wages up to October 30th, we have on hand $303.05 we will account for all expenditures up to the end of October this week if possible. I have had to purchase some nails, wire etc. as well as pay wages from this advance and regret to advise that a further advance of $200.00 for wages may still be necessary to complete the building, interior painting, and installation of the heating system.

In regard to the furniture for the teacherage I will prepare a requisition after visiting the school on Friday as I will then be in a better position to know just what will be required. A good size cook stove range will be necessary and arrangements should also be made for a supply of furnace coal. The coal could no doubt be purchased in Grandview or Roblin and delivered by truck to the coal bin. However, there is sufficient seasoned wood on hand to do for a couple of months.

J. L. Bryant,
Superintendent.
Pelly Agency.

P.S. Mr. Banville estimates that he will take until Nov 27th to finish all the work at the school. With Mr. Banville at 15¢ per hour 4 carpenters & 12¢ per hour one or two helpers at 75¢ per hour pay will come approximately $400 per week.

Indian Affairs Branch,

Re: Valley River School Supplies Cement.

With reference to your telegram of October 29, I would advise that I shipped 157 sacks of cement to Superintendent F. Booth of Qu'Appelle Agency. This cement was shipped collect to Lottie, Saskatchewan for use of the Black Bear Band.

This cement cost $89.72 per sack F.O.B. Timberton. Unloading and reloading again cost an additional 10 cents per sack, so the charge to Black Bear Band will be at the rate of $99.72 cents per sack.

I used 15 sacks of the Timberton cement at Cote Day School and also allowed the National Lumber Yards at Timberton to purchase 25 sacks at a time that they urgently required it and we knew we had considerably more than would be required. This firm made every effort to get our building material for the school and it was very difficult to get considerable of the material when it was required.

The understanding was that they would credit us for the cement when their account was rendered. However, when the account was submitted this was overlooked.

Mr. Gowan will be advised of this matter when we turn over all our Valley River accounts and records on Friday of this week and will see that the necessary adjustment is made.

J. L. Bryant,
Superintendent.
Pelly Agency.
Re: Valley River New Day School

I have visited this school every week with the exception of one since construction started. Mr. Allbright the Assistant, at Valley River Reserve is there almost every day and we feel satisfied that the workmanship has been very satisfactory but I must admit that it has taken more for wages to pay the carpenters and helpers than was expected.

Wages are paid up to the week ending November 27, and Mr. Banville and his two sons will still take all this week to complete the finishing work inside. The weekly wage for these three men amounts to $240.00 for 6-10 hour days.

I am turning over Valley River Reserve to Dauphin Agency at the end of November. I have $34.50 on hand which will be returned to you with an accounting for all expenditures since October 31.

There is also Income Tax deductions outstanding for the weeks ending October 30, to November 27, in the amount of $226.82. It is assumed that you will send the Manitoba Income Tax Director a cheque for this amount when you receive the time sheets. I would also suggest that you send Mr. Wm. Gowan's Superintendent, of Dauphin Agency, a further $400.00 to take care of wages until the job is completed.

This school has a pleasing appearance on the outside, is well laid out inside and I am sure will be most comfortable for the teacher and pupils.

J. L. Bryant,
Superintendent,
Pelly Agency.
December 3, 1948.

Mr. J.L. Bryant,
Superintendent, Felly Agency,
Kamsack, Saskatchewan.

Re: Valley River Indian Day School

We are pleased to note from your letters of November 29 and 30 that satisfactory progress is being maintained in the construction of this school.

We are sending a copy of this letter to Mr. Gowans and are also sending him an accountable advance of $400.00 to take care of wages until the job is completed.

We are referring the question of Income Tax deductions to our Chief Treasury Officer.

It is noted that we will receive a credit from the National Lumber Yards for the twenty-five sacks of cement allotted to them. It would be appreciated if we could have photographs of this school when it is completed. These are most helpful to the Department in future years.

Bernard F. Henry,

Memorandum:

CHIEF TREASURY OFFICER

Re: Valley River Indian Day School No. 632

We have received a letter from Mr. Indian Superintendent Bryant concerning the construction of the above school. In this he states as follows:

"I am turning over Valley River Reserve to Dauphin Agency at the end of November. I have a $34.50 on hand which will be returned to you with an accounting for all expenditures since October 31.

There is also Income Tax deductions outstanding for the weeks ending October 30, to November 27, in the amount of $226.82. It is assumed that you will send the Manitoba Income Tax Director a cheque for this amount when you receive the time sheets. I would also suggest that you send Mr. Wm. Gowans' Superintendent, of Dauphin Agency, a further $400.00 to take care of wages until the job is completed."

Please find attached a requisition for cheque in the amount of $400.00 to be forwarded to Mr. William Gowans of the Dauphin Agency.

Could you please advise with regard to the Income Tax deductions.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.
December 9, 1948.

Mr. J. L. Bryant,
Superintendent, Pelly Indian Agency,
Kamsack, Saskatchewan.

Valley River Indian Day School.

Further to my letter of December 3, please be advised that the Chief Treasury Officer has discussed with me the matter of the final accountable advance for the construction of this school.

He feels that this advance should be sent to you in view of the fact that all previous accountable advances have been passed through your office.

Therefore a cheque for $400.00 will reach you in the near future in order that you might carry out the final payments for labour at this school.

I am sending a copy of this letter to Mr. Davis and to Mr. Gowans so that they will be aware of the change made.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Ottawa, May 17, 1910.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 5th instant, in which you state that the Indians of the Valley River Reserve have the logs and lumber with which to build a new school-house on the ground.

In reply I beg to say that, in view of the evident earnestness of these Indians, the Department will supply them with the windows, doors, nails, tar paper and lime, as well as the tools mentioned by you, the total cost not to exceed your quotation. On the completion of the work these tools may be distributed as you think best among the Indians who performed the labour.

The Department will also consent to the opening of the school after the summer holidays and to the temporary appointment of Annie Clair Rattlemake at a salary of $300.00 per annum, provided a qualified teacher is not available before that date. You will be good enough to make every effort to secure the services of a satisfactory teacher. It is not considered advisable to open the school for the short period intervening between this date and the 30th of June and no doubt the new building will be completed in time for the opening of the school after the holidays.

When nearing completion you may purchase 10 double desks, table, two chairs, heating stove and pipes. I may add that the cost of the articles quoted by you appears to be reasonable except in the case of the desks, which are rather

W. G. Blewett, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kamsack, Sask.
high. Be good enough to state if this is the best price you can obtain for desks of the style specified and also if the price for the heating stove is reasonable.

A requisition for books and other supplies may be sent in at least a month before the opening of the school. The Department would like to know whether you can purchase hyloplate blackboards at any point there and, if so, at what price.

Mention was not made by you in your last letter in regard to the site. The building should be erected on property belonging to the Band. The site should be high and dry and at least one acre should be available in order that a garden may be conducted at a later date. The building operations should be carefully watched to insure good workmanship and a satisfactory structure when completed.

Your obedient servant,

Secretary.
Sir,

Referring to your letter of No. 145277/1.

I beg to say that when at Valley River paying Annuity on the 3rd inst. I found that the walls of the School House were up and the Indians are trying to have the whole building finished by the 1st of July. It is on a high and dry site and an acre or more of land will be left for garden or other school wants. I instructed Mr Chard to keep a close watch on the work to have it well done. I gave him a list of the tools and building material allowed and he was to buy them on Saturday last. I am enclosing herewith a list of School Material needed for opening the School as soon as completed. I saw a local dealer at Grandview about Desks and chairs, table &c and find that by sending to Toronto for Desks we can get them for $5.50 or $6.00 each so ordered them from there, it will take a little longer getting them that is all. The same merchant has agreed to get us the hyloplate too for blackboard. I have heard that there is a teacher qualified at Grandview who might take the school I expect to hear from her shortly and will send her application on to the Department for consideration.

Your obedient Servant,

Indian Agent,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

MEMORANDUM:

GARSON LAKE

After discussion with Priests, Hudson's Bay Agents and others who could speak authoritatively of this settlement, I decided not to ask for transportation to the place.

It is generally agreed that the Indians who live there and who are a sort of lost group of wanderers from Alberta, face a dismal economic future. The lake is drying up and ruining the chances of survival by other means than relief doles. The Church, the Hudson's Bay Company and Inspector Ostrander have been trying for several years to get these Indians to move to a more favourable location, preferably to a place called Bull's Head, near Peter Pond Lake, where there are fishing possibilities for farming and hay and the prospect of a road to Lake La Loche. The obstructionist is Chief Alfonse Piapot who is abetted by some of the older people for what are said to be entirely sentimental reasons. It may be that the withdrawal of artificial means of support would convince them that settlement elsewhere is mandatory.

There is no reason to build a school at the present settlement, but if the Band would move to Bull's Head, construction of a two-room school would be justifiable. Nursing service would be available at La Loche or Ile a la Crosse, 50 miles in either direction.

C.A.F. Clark,
Educational Surveys.

CAFC/EM
April 10th, 1947.

Schools Required in Northern Saskatchewan.

1. Fond du Lac. (Roman Catholic)

Statements received from: Rev. Pere Gamsche, H.B. Coy's agent (black), Constable Duffy, R.C.M.P. all on 4 April, 1947.

During the past winter there were enough Indian children on the spot to fill a two-room school. About $2000 a month was handed out in family allowances. The children speak only the tribal tongue. Across the lake there are about 6 or 8 children who are the province's charge. At Fond du Lac it is definitely our move. We'd need land.

The H.B. Coy will let us have a building about 24' by 18' which with some fixing up could become an immediate token of our good intentions. It will need some windows added to one side and a good heater.

Freight, including blackboards, desks and classroom expendables should be at Waterways by June 1st. The first barge usually arrives at Fond du Lac during the last week in June.

For new construction we should begin with a two-room building adaptable for conversion into a four-room school. A nursing station-residence should follow. Meanwhile, the H.B. agent could accommodate one woman teacher. For a man teacher a small "house" is available.

The situation appears to be one which we should exploit without delay. Admittedly the transportation of desks, etc., will be expensive (and we might as well send good ones) but the need for these things will persist and more will likely be required next year.

C.A.F. Clark,

AIRMAIL

Ottawa, April 30, 1947.

The Agent,
Hudson's Bay Company,
Fond du Lac, Saskatchewan.

Dear Sir:

Reference is to your conversation with our Educational Survey Officer, Mr. Clark, on April 4, at which time you very kindly offered to make available:

(a) a vacant building for temporary use as a school,

(b) accommodation in your own home for a lady teacher, or

(c) a small house suitable for a male teacher.

In order that a teacher may be appointed as soon as possible, your answers and comments are requested as follows:

(1) Do you prefer to rent or to sell the buildings (a) and (c) above, and what is the rental or purchase price in each case?

(2) What would you charge a lady teacher for accommodation?

(3) If you prefer to rent the buildings, are you willing to permit extra-windows to be cut in the one to be used for school purposes?

(4) Other than the adjustments required for use as a classroom, what repairs do you consider necessary to both buildings?
(5) Are there good stoves in the buildings? If not, have you any suitable heaters in stock which we might buy?

(6) Can you equip the teacherage, if necessary, from your stock of kitchenware and bedroom necessities?

(7) Have you any suggestions regarding the construction and siting of toilets?

The use of the buildings under discussion is, of course, only a temporary expedient pending design and construction of indicated requirements. Permanent installations can only be built on land to which the Dominion Government holds title. Information concerning the owners and probable prices of suitable sites is desired. An acre of ground is considered necessary. It is hoped eventually to make the best possible educational facilities available to all the children of the settlement. Your help in studying the problem is most welcome.

Yours very truly,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Chet:

I do not know to whom I should offer condolence for the loss of those four airplanes on Saturday—to the Insurance Company I hope. I hope also that your replacement problem will not result in any inconvenience to your flying in the Northern School Teachers, a month hence. There is a slight touch of self-interest in all this, as it is our intention here to get that school at Fond du Lac going this fall. The supplies are on order to go up on the last boat which is scheduled to leave on the 6th of September, but the Canadian Pacific Air-Lines, if I read their folder correctly, no longer maintain a regular service along the Athabasca Lakes. As you will have to get a teacher into Stony Rapids, I wonder whether we can come to some arrangement, providing, of course, that we are successful in obtaining a teacher for Fond du Lac.

I understand your Traveling Motion Picture Man gave a show in the old building at Fond du Lac which we now have permission to convert to school use, and so we should be able to accommodate most of the Indian and non-Indian children who really want to attend school.
when I was in Edmonton last month, I tried twice to communicate with you by telephone but had no luck. Early next month I am due at Norway House, Manitoba, where the agent is having to charter a plane so that we can collect data on educational needs in North-Eastern Manitoba. It may turn out that I will be in North-Western, Manitoba and North-Eastern Saskatchewan. I will let you know what develops.

Yours most sincerely,

G.A.F. Clark,

Re: Fond Du Lac, Day School Building.

While on patrol to the Fond Du Lac area lately I looked over the temporary building that is to be used for a school, and it was decided that a complete floor would be put down on top of the old one, which would level a very uneven one and would also add greatly to the heat of the building, only one extra window will put in owing to the condition of the walls which would not stand much cutting. Walls are to be repaired outside and inside the building banked up with sand, paint will be forwarded from here and the inside will be painted cream which will possibly offset any darkness that might be caused by want of sufficient windows. Two toilets will be erected at a reasonable distance from the school.

All necessary supplies for this repair work are available at this point, and the labour will be local and mostly Indian. It is hard to estimate the cost as there is no skilled labour available there but Mr Black will supervise.

A supply of wood has already been cut and as this was green wood a larger supply was cut so that there would be some available for the following winter, for this winter green wood will have to be traded with The H.B.Co for dry wood so that at least half green and half dry wood can be used. The approx. cost of this wood is $490.00 or one year's cost approximately $350.00.

I would mention that even if a teacher is available school could not be opened until the school supplies are received there which will about September 15th.

THIS LEASE is subject to the covenants and powers implied except as modified herein and subject also to the payment of the rents herein reserved and to the following covenants, provisos, conditions and stipulations. The Lessee covenants and agrees with the Lessor as follows:

1. That the Lessee shall and will well and truly pay or cause to be paid to the Lessor at the Office of the Land Department of the Lessor at the City of Winnipeg, in Manitoba, or at such other place as may be designated by the Lessor, the rent hereby reserved.
2. That the Lessee will at all times during the continuance of this lease keep and at the termination thereof yield up the demised property in good and tenable repair, accidents and damage to buildings from fire, storm or tempest and unavoidable wear and tear excepted, provided however that the Lessee's obligation under this covenant shall not extend to repairs to the foundation, walls, roof, structural posts and beams of the building unless damage to the said foundation, walls, roof, structural posts and beams shall be caused by negligence of the Lessee, his invitees or licencees.

The Lessee agrees to notify the Lessor promptly of any condition in the foundation, walls, roof and structural parts of the building which may require repair and the Lessor shall be under no liability for failure to repair.

3. That the Lessee will not cut down timber or trees and will provide receptacles for rubbish and refuse of all kinds and will attend to the removal of same from the premises at regular intervals, and will remove any rubbish, ice or snow from the roof and eaves of the demised property and from all walks, passages, yards and alleys adjacent to the demised property.

4. That the Lessor or its agents may enter upon the demised property and view the state of repair thereof and may give the Lessee a notice in writing of any defect requiring the Lessee, within a reasonable time to be mentioned therein, to repair the same.

5. That the Lessee will pay and discharge the annual taxes payable in respect of buildings erected or improvements made by the Lessee on the demised property under the terms hereof, and all rates, taxes, assessments and impositions whatsoever imposed or charged upon occupiers of the demised property, including, without limiting the generality of the foregoing, all business taxes and all rates or charges for water, electricity, gas and meters, and for similar services for or in respect of the demised property or the business carried on therein.

6. That the Lessee will not without leave assign or sublet.

7. That the Lessee will not use or allow the demised property to be used for any business or purpose other than that hereinbefore stated, and will not permit on the demised property any sales by auction nor any work, business, occupation, act or thing whatever which may be or become a nuisance or annoyance to the Lessor, the public or any other occupant of the Lessor's property, or which may increase the hazard of fire or liability of any kind, or which may increase the premium rate of insurance against loss by fire or liability upon the Lessor's property or invalidate any policy of insurance of any kind upon or in respect of same. The Lessee will not, except with the consent of the Lessor, erect any building thereon or hang or suspend from any building any sign or other projection in the carrying on of its business and the Lessee will comply with all Municipal By-laws, and with all the laws of the Province and of Canada relating to the business which may be carried on by the Lessee in the demised property or the occupation thereof, and with all the regulations and requirements of the insurance companies insuring any part of the property applicable thereto and approved by the Lessor.

8. That the Lessee will indemnify and keep indemnified the Lessor against all actions, suits, liens, claims and demands, by any person or persons whomsoever in respect of any loss, injury, claim, damage or obligation to compensate arising out of or connected with any works carried on by the Lessee within or upon the demised property, or services or material supplied for or in respect thereof, and also in respect of any loss, injury, lien, claim or damage arising out of or connected with the breach of any of the terms and conditions of this lease, or by reason of any suspended sign on the demised property. If the Lessor shall suffer or incur any damage, loss or expense or be obliged to make any payment for which the Lessee is liable hereunder by reason of any failure of the Lessee to observe and comply with any of the covenants of the Lessee herein contained, then the Lessor shall have the right to add the cost or amount of any such damage, loss, expense or payment to the rent hereby reserved, and any such amount shall thereupon immediately be due and payable as rent and recoverable in the manner provided by law for the recovery of rent in arrear.

9. That the Lessee will, during the term of this lease, permit the Lessor or its agents to place upon any part of the demised property a notice offering the same for sale, and will during the two calendar months immed-
iately preceding the termination of this lease, permit the Lessor or its agents to place upon any part of the demised property a notice offering the same for rent, and the Lessee will during the currency of this lease permit prospective purchasers and tenants and others in authority from the Lessor or its agents, at reasonable times, to view the demised property.

10. That the Lessee will not erect any buildings on the demised property during the said term, nor make any structural alterations in the buildings thereon without the written consent of the Lessor, and the Lessee will erect such buildings, and make such alterations at his own expense, and without any right to compensation from the Lessor. At the expiration or termination of this lease, the Lessee shall not have any right to remove any such new buildings or erections, but they shall become and remain part of the demised property.

11. That the Lessee will give to the Lessor immediate notice of any defect in the water, gas or other pipes or fixtures, heating apparatus, elevator, hoist machinery, electric wires or fixtures and of any condition which may cause injury to the demised property.

12. That the Lessee, without prejudice to the Lessor's right to distrain for rent at any time, and to all its rights and remedies, will pay to the Lessor in case any rent hereunder shall at any time remain unpaid, interest upon such rent at the rate of six per cent (6%) per annum from the day for payment thereof to the day of payment thereof.

13. That the Lessee will observe, obey, and conform to and cause his employees to observe, obey and conform to reasonable rules and regulations made from time to time by the Lessor with regard to the management, use or occupation of the demised property.

14. That no waiver on behalf of the Lessor of any breach of any of the covenants, provisions, conditions or stipulations herein contained, whether express or implied, or negative or positive in form, shall take effect or be binding upon the Lessor unless the same is in writing under the authority of the Lessor, and any waiver so expressed shall extend only to the particular breach so waived and shall not limit or affect the Lessor's rights with respect to any other or future breach.

15. That in case the Lessor should sell or agree to sell or require for any purpose the demised property during the term of this lease, it may at its option forthwith give notice thereof to the Lessee, and in such case this lease shall cease and be at an end following the giving of such notice.

16. That in case the demised property shall at any time during the said term be destroyed or damaged by fire so as to be unfit for occupation and use, and the policy or policies of insurance effected by the Lessor shall not have been vitiated, or payment of the insurance monies refused, in consequence of some act of the Lessee, the rent hereby reserved on a fair proportion thereof according to the nature and extent of the damage sustained, shall be suspended until the demised property shall be again rendered fit for occupation and use. In the event of the total destruction, damage or failure of the demised property by fire, cyclone, tempest, decay or any other cause, or such partial destruction, damage or failure as in the judgment of the Lessor does not warrant the repairing or rebuilding of it, the Lessor may within thirty days after such destruction, damage or failure give notice to the Lessee terminating this lease.

17. That any elevator, loading platform, service room, passage, lane or yard connected with the demised property is for the use of all the occupants of the property of the Lessor to which the same is appurtenant, and the Lessee will not obstruct nor hinder the use of same by the Lessor, its employees, agents, customers or tenants.

18. That the sole and exclusive right to use or lease to others for their use, the roof or the exteriors of the side and the rear walls of the demised property is retained by the Lessor.

22. That if the Lessee should hold over, and the Lessor should accept rent after the expiration of the said term, the new tenancy thereby created shall be a tenancy from month to month, and not a tenancy from year to year, and shall be subject to the covenants and conditions herein contained so far as the same are applicable to a tenancy from month to month.

23. That if the term hereby granted shall at any time be seized or taken in execution or attachment by any creditor of the Lessee, or if the Lessee shall make any assignment for the benefit of creditors, or become bankrupt or insolvent, or shall take the benefit of any Act that may be in force for bankrupt or insolvent debtors, then three months' rent shall thereupon become due and payable, and this lease and all rights and privileges hereby granted shall, at the option of the Lessor, cease and be at an end, notwithstanding anything to the contrary.

Note,- The purpose of Form C is to ascertain the total of the possible
number of days the pupils in each school could have attended had
they attended, during the school year 1945-46, every day the school
was available for them from the day they entered (first enrolled for
the year) to the end of the school year, or to the day they withdrew
if they withdrew before the end of the school year. For example it
would not be possible for a pupil who entered on October 1, 1945,
to attend as many days as a pupil who entered on September 1, 1945,
provided they both remained in attendance until June 30, 1946. In
calculating the totals under the above headings ignore absences due
to causes which did not involve permanent withdrawal, e.g., illness,
attending a funeral (unless the whole class was dismissed), being
kept at home to work, etc. That is to say, ignore absences when the
school was in operation and available for use so far as the school
authorities were concerned. This is the meaning of "possible atten-
dance" for present purposes.

Colonel Heary:

Desks,
Fond du Lac School:
Reference your wire to Sept. Stewart, dated 5 inst.,
regarding provision of more desks.

The school has 28 desks. The classroom is
only about 24' by 18'. They seem to have
little enough space already. With desks so
expensive and in short supply we might
rather consider the adoption of a part-
time schedule.

The age-grade distribution for last term
makes me think that attendance was on a
selective basis. Perhaps it would be better to
give a 100% part-time coverage rather than
to cram them all in all day or allow
some to avoid school completely.

C.A.V. Clark
Colonel Henry:

Fond du Lac Teacherage - furnishings:
Reference to agent's telegram:

1. At the present one linoleum rug should suffice (9'x12')
2. The studio couch ("sofa") to replace "bed only."
3. A kitchen table and three kitchen chairs would be more appropriate to the set-up than the buffet table, etc.
4. An axe has already been provided.
5. Coal should not be needed much.
6. You have little pillows. I urge that an exception be made (similarly to N.W.T.) and that bedding be purchased from local H.B. post. As the Hudson's Bay Company's co-operation is a factor, purchases from them either at Edmonton or Fond du Lac might well be as large as from other sources.
7. Hope Stewart is building cupboards or shelves to hold the assortment of kitchenware.

C.A. T. Clark

Dear Sir:

Attached hereto please find estimated quotation on materials required for Teacherage at Fond du Lac, Saskatchewan, as requested by Mr. J. W. Stewart, Superintendent of Fort Chipewyan in his letter of July 21st.

There are one or two things about this quotation which we would like to draw to your attention. The first is that Mr. Stewart informs us that the walls are to be of log construction but he does not mention how thick these walls are. We have taken it for granted that they will be about seven inches thick and if they are less than that or more than that, then there will have to be some changes made in the window and door jams. Also we note that he asked us to quote on the window and door frames. We did not do this, as delivery on frames at the present in Edmonton is very bad and we have therefore listed materials required to make these up and you can have the carpenter do this on the job, which will save you money and besides give you good service.

The next thing we would like to draw to your attention is the fact that we quoted on our Selkirk prefabricated chimney for this job as it will be more economical than shipping bricks and lime etc. into Fond du Lac. A couple of labourers can easily install this chimney in a few hours. It is a very good chimney and we are shipping quite a number of these to the North West Territories at the present time. We enclose herewith literature which we have on these chimneys.

Mr. Stewart indicates in his letter that he wished this material to be shipped with the least possible delay. Therefore if we are successful in getting this business we will appreciate having your reply so that we can have this material prepared for shipping.

We note from the schedule we have on hand that the last boat leaves for Fond du Lac on September 4th and we should have a little time at least in which to get materials prepared for shipment. We do not think there is anything on this bill of material that we cannot supply on fairly short notice. The windows would no doubt have to be made in our factory here or possibly some of them and this would take about one weeks time to manufacture. Outside of this item the balance of the material is all in Waterways at the present time.

There is also one other thing. Mr. Stewart did not mention in his letter what he wanted to put on the outside of the building and therefore we were unable to quote on this. We are in a position to offer you Insul-brick Siding, Cedar Siding or Spruce Drop Siding whichever you might require. If you decide to put any of these materials on the building, we would only be too pleased to quote you on them.
It has been rather difficult for us to quote very accurately on the materials required for this building in view of the fact that the plan which we received was not any too clear. However, we feel that you have more than enough material listed on this quotation to do the job should you decide to go ahead with it. We can assure you that we will do our utmost to have the material shipped as quickly as possible after receiving your order.

Yours very truly,

HAYWARD'S LUMBER CO. LIMITED

(sgd) L. A. Carbert

Re: Day School, Fond du Lac, Athabasca Indian Agency

When Superintendent Stewart attended the conference of Superintendents in Calgary last week he reported that the Rev. Father Gamache informed him when he paid Treaty at Fond du Lac in June that he is not prepared to continue to teach the day school. It will be necessary therefore to find another teacher.

There is no accommodation for a teacher and an item of $5,000 was included in the estimates to build a teacherage. The season is now so far advanced that it would be next to impossible to bring in much building material or erect a frame building. Therefore I suggested to Mr. Stewart that he investigate the possibilities of building a two-room log house, using Indian labour to get out logs and employ qualified Indians or Metis to erect it.

He is going there to investigate a report that the Indians are destitute and will arrange for the construction of this building if he finds that logs can be readily secured and labour to construct the building is available. Furthermore, this will give much needed employment to these Indians. He stated that he could obtain the necessary finishing material from McMurray. The cost of such a building should be considerably less than $5,000 and should be quite comfortable for a single person or a married couple. Immediate action was necessary and I hope you approve.

Extract from letter of Mr. Agent Macarthur, dated August 4th, 1909.

I had a meeting with the Indians of the Nut Lake Reserve on July 27th, nearly all of the band being present. I was disappointed to find that the whole band was against having a school opened on the Reserve. One man did say that if a school was opened, he would send his children, but as the others were against it he had no more to say. The Indians of this band are in many ways a fine body of men that one can't help feeling could be made into successful farmers if they could be got to settle down. They are very independent and I think that the real underlying objection to a school is a fear that by accepting it they would in some way part with some of their freedom.

The question must stand until a Farmer is placed on the reserve. He may, after a time, by judicious tact overcome their prejudices.
Sir,

I have to bring to your notice that Farmer Hamilton of the Nut Lake Reserve in making his report states that those Indians who have children, are anxious to have a school established for them.

I understand that at the last Treaty payment this request was made by them to the late Agent, and when visiting the reserve during the winter Farmer Hamilton as well as one of the Indians spoke about the matter, but as our time was fully occupied we did not go into details.

For the Department's guidance, it would appear that there are upward of 50 children of school age, all of whom, like the rest of the band are Pagans, and I fancy there is only one or two who can speak English. As you are aware the Reserve is about 40 miles from Wadena on the main line of the Canadian Northern, and in the past the band have lived by hunting. During the past few years the whole of this country has been settled up, with the exception of a strip to the north for about 30 miles. It is expected that the Thunder Hill branch of the C.N.R will pass near the reserve, in which case the bands hunting grounds would to a large extent be closed. This matter of hunting with the Nut Lake people is a most difficult one, and as the country gets more settled up these hunting disputes are likely to become more numerous, and it would be to their interests to do as much as possible to enable the younger men to get a living from their farming operations. At present they are farming in a small way, the drawback being the distance to haul their grain, they are however making more of a success with their cattle, as there is a large quantity of hay.
around the reserve and lake. At the same time also when they find themselves hemmed in by the settlers, unless they can obtain a living from their farms the rationing of so large a band is likely to be on the increase.

Under these circumstances the establishment of a school is a matter that might have consideration. It has been found that the school in some cases keeps the people from wandering about the country so much, which to a small extent keeps them on the farm. During the settling up of the country it would be wrong, as well as expensive, to allow the young men to grow up with only their hunting abilities to depend on for a living. There are one or two young men here on the Beardys reserve who are a continue worry to themselves, and everyone in a small way. They are never settled. Also the Nut Lake men cannot speak English, which is a difficulty, as the younger men cannot hire out with the neighbouring farmers so easily as those who know what his employer is talking about, and in a year or two the whole of the reserve will be surrounded by white people.

I understood from Mr Swinford that when he was Agent at Touchwood many years ago, and had charge of this band, these people were almost wild and very troublesome; if this is so their request for a school goes along way to show that in having a Farmer with them, and what little contact they have had with the white settlers, they are beginning to realize that it is a good thing for the children to receive education, also it might be the means of their giving up their Pagan belief in years to come. At the same time they are so very touchy that the whole matter would depend, as far as success goes, on the teacher.

It would be absolutely necessary to have someone who has had experience in Indian schools, however I expect the matter will come up next time I visit the reserve, and I would be glad of any suggestions the Department might make, that I could place before these people if they question me on the matter.

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.

I have the honour to be,

Sir

Your obedient servant.

Dear Sir,

I address this letter to you as instructed, and I ask your assistance and advice towards obtaining my request. It is a matter of such importance that I would ask you to bring it before the Minister of Indian Affairs at the earliest possible opportunity, and also to see that the matter is not dropped after it is opened up.

My work and the work of my missionaries among our Indians gives us the opportunity of learning their state, their needs, their desires, in a way that you will rarely learn from your Indian Agents and Instructors. I beg therefore, to press upon your Dept. the pressing need of Day Schools as follows; (among others perhaps not mentioned) I am sure the I.D. knows of the non-existence of such schools and of the desire of the Indians to have them, and perhaps the I.D. has been considering the matter. But I would press for the building and maintaining of these schools almost immediately. (1) The Indians are retrograding and suffering for the lack (2) It does not seem in accordance with "Treaty" to leave them without. (3) They desire and ask for them. I cannot be sure of correct names, but I think what I write is sufficient to point them out correctly.

1.- Frog Lake, Nos. 121 and 122, but especially Conceptionwhao (121) We have worked here for years, but there has been no school. They sent a few children to Onion Lake Boarding School. They will no longer do so as they want the day school system. I have sent a Cree teacher there Ch. Quinaly, an intelligent educated man (half breed) I think), to open school as best he can in his own house, or
in the Indian houses. I have to build a house for him. This is not fair to the Church funds which are not meant for schools. I beg to apply (1) for his salary, (2) for purchase of the residence for him (3) for a school to be built (4) for an improved day school to be maintained.

N.B.- I would recommend the closing of Onion Lake school as hearing school and opening it as improved day school.

2.- Island Lake Band Nos. 161 and 161A.

We visit them and hold service there. They belong to our Church more than to any other. They come in at times to Onion Lake Church. They should have a school and we are prepared to undertake it on the usual terms.

3.- Thunderchild Band. South from Bright Land Lake.

It is really a shame that the I.D. has (I believe) given them no school or teacher since they were moved to this location. My missionary visits them, but only too rarely since they were moved so far away from his other bands. They should have a good improved day school. The Church of England should be intrusted with its management.

4.- Nut Lake Band No. 90.

Sir,

While at Nut Lake I found a student, I think of the Methodist church, supposedly teaching school there. I understand he was there nearly two months under pay from the Government before the Department knew of his appointment. He had been sent to that point by Mr. Ferries of Brandon without the knowledge or consent of the Department. I found him living in the house of "Little Cree" where he was supposedly teaching school. The house is a little bit of a shanty about 18 X 14, in it there lived about ten people and the dogs. I found this young fellow about two o'clock in the afternoon in his stocking feet, holes in the slack of his pants, no coat and with the appearance of not having washed or combed his hair for a week. I think myself he was having an afternoon nap.

He told me he had two pupils, children of "Little Cree", a little boy and girl, neither of whom as far as I could find out knew B from a bull's foot. Teaching of some kind is certainly necessary on this reserve but it is absolutely necessary that it should be undertaken by one qualified to teach and under the guidance and auspices of the Department. There are dozens of children on this reserve who are of school age and who would be benefitted by having among them a proper teacher. Take for instance the family of the Indian who was burned in the Farm Instructor's house trying to save the books of the Agency. There are 12 children left by him divided among his widows, at least 7 of these I think are of school age. The young school teacher there I would say was absolutely unfitted for the position and the work, though his aspirations are of the best.
Knowing the language I could hear the remarks made by Indians regarding him and they were not very flattering. You can understand if a man has not the regard and respect of the Indians he can be of little use among them. I bring this to your attention with the hope that before another spring arrangements may be made after consulting with the Inspector in charge of that district and the Farm Instructor to have a school of some kind properly run on this reserve.

Yours &c.,

Sir,

I beg to report to the Department that I have just returned from a visit to the Nut Lake Reserve and when there at a meeting of the Indians who were present on the reserve I impressed upon them the desire of the Department that they send their children to school. I have informed them that they have a choice of schools to which they may send their children and at each of the schools their children will not only be taught to read and write English but they will also be given a practical training in general housekeeping, soil culture and the care of stock. I have made an earnest effort during the past year to overcome the objection of the members of this band to education. Have pointed out the fact that their hunting grounds are being rapidly settled up and it will only be a matter of a short period of time until they will of necessity be compelled to abandon their present mode of making a living and they will then have to make their living by cultivating the soil and that they are not doing their duty to their children if they do not embrace the opportunity afforded by our schools of equipping their children with the education and training so necessary in the management of their business and which will enable them to become self supporting, self respecting and useful citizens.

There are at present about seventy children of School age belonging to the Nut Lake Band and only two

of this number are now attending school.

They are a fine, healthy looking lot of children. The members of this Band make their living chiefly by hunting and trapping. Dear Mr. Graham,

I have your letter of the 20th instant, mentioning the request of Mr. John A. Ward that he be given some assistance for the purpose of erecting a day school on the Nut Lake Reserve.

We realize the need of educational facilities at this point. There are approximately 60 physically fit children of school age on this Reserve, and it appears that there are only 4 receiving any schooling (1 at Brandon and 3 at Lebret).

Dear Sir,

An Agent of Indian Affairs called the other day to see me in reference to the Nut Lake Indian Reserve work about which I wrote you last October. He spoke about a school on the Reserve. I beg to report that when paying Treaty at Nut Lake on the 29th ult., I took a list of all children of school age and found that there were almost fifty between the ages of seven and fifteen. I told the Indians that these children would have to attend school and that if they came forward voluntarily the choice of a school would be left as far as possible with the parents.

In spite of this there was not one Indian who would give his consent to have his children sent to school; they were all very strongly opposed to the idea.

Under the circumstances, and in view of the number of children involved, I did not care to take the responsibility of using coercive measures, so I allowed the matter to stand until I had placed the facts before the Department.

Dear Mr. Murphy; Nut Lake Indian Reserve.

This Reserve is about 7 or 8 miles from Rose Valley and there are in the neighborhood of 375 to 400 Indians on the reserve. There is no school or anything on the reserve for training these Indians and no one seems to have any interest in them. There are a very quiet class and as long as Liquor and Extracts are kept away from them they are law abiding. Wm Gilchrist, is, Resident Farmer, but not much farming is done and the young Indians are allowed to drift along like savages. Now is it right to allow this when church organizations are collecting for foreign missions to educate the people in foreign countries.

Besides this Reserve is situated in between Kelvington and Ponass Lake Municipalities, two of the best Municipalities in the Province of Saskatchewan. There is a population of around 8000 people and the Government owe it to the white people to see that something is done with them.

I would suggest a Government Indian School and farm right on the south side of the Reserve and near the Big Nut Lake. The land is well suited for cultivation and they should be taught to produce their own food. The influx of settlers to all lands north of the Reserve is destroying fur bearing animals and big game and eventually if this is not done the Indians will be on relief. It would be much better to try something now before it is too late.

Yours sincerely,

(Sgd) J. B. Lorimer.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Departmental letter No. 121-81, dated the 12th ultimo, with reference to a request which has been received by the Honourable the Minister that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children of the Nut Lake Reserve in the Touchwood Agency.

I have discussed the matter with Indian Agent Waddy and find that he holds the same views as myself with regard to the attitude of the Nut Lake Indians towards education; that is that their attitude has not changed. They are strongly opposed to any interference with their aboriginal beliefs and I do not think that more than four or five of this Band profess to belong to a religious denomination and they cannot be classed as very strong adherents to Christianity. I was in charge of this Reserve as Indian Agent for over fifteen years and during that period I made a very determined effort to recruit children from the Nut Lake Band for the residential schools in the Touchwood and Qu'Appelle Agencies with very little success. I think during that period I was only successful in obtaining three or four recruits. These unfortunately died either in the school or shortly after their return, which did not tend to make the Indians feel more kindly towards our schools. Mr. Waddy informs me that he has never had a request during his term as Agent from any of the Indians of the Nut Lake Band with regard to obtaining educational facilities for their children.

Apart from this, even if there were a friendly feeling towards the question on the part of the Band (which there is decidedly not), the very nature of their means of subsistence would not incline me to recommend the expenditure of money in the establishment of a school on this Reserve. The Indians obtain their livelihood by trapping and hunting in the winter months, digging seneca root, working for settlers, scrubbing land, and the sale of pickets during the summer months. The country to the northeast of their Reserve is a large forest reserve and practically uninhabited. These Indians have used this as a trapping ground for generations. From about the middle of February until the end of May practically the only Indians left on the Reserve are the old and destitute who are on the annuity list. The able-bodied Indians who of course have the large families are all away earning their living and, as they have no means of leaving their children on the Reserve, they have to take them along. Again their occupation during the summer of digging seneca root and scrubbing land for settlers takes them away from their Reserve.

It will be readily understood that under these conditions the prospect of obtaining even a small regular attendance would be very doubtful. The older men on the Reserve are bitterly opposed to—

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
bitterly opposed to changing their belief and their influence is dominant amongst the younger people, and so long as they have to obtain their subsistence by following their present avocation their influence will remain the same.

In my opinion we might be well advised to encourage the Principals of the residential schools to make a determined effort to recruit young children from this Reserve; and, if successful, which I doubt at present, in time the influence of these young people after they have received some years of training might gradually have the effect of other Indians assuming a more kindly attitude with regard to education.

No doubt there are missionaries and others who, without a knowledge of the efforts that have been made in the past and without full information regarding the mode of livelihood of these Indians, will take the viewpoint that they are being neglected. This is not correct however. The Indians appear to be contented with their present mode of living and the only request they made to me during the many years I was there was that they be left alone to enjoy their own beliefs. Until the time arrives when it is imperative that they settle down to farming and stock raising on the Reserve as a source of livelihood, I do not consider it advisable to incur the expenditure which would be involved in the establishment of a day school on the Reserve. It would simply mean providing a position for a teacher, and I question very much if the influence of a school on the Reserve would have the effect of raising the standard of civilization amongst these Indians until such time as they change their attitude towards this question.

It will be seen by the foregoing that neither myself nor Mr. Waddy concur in the recommendation that a day school be established. In view of this I hardly consider it necessary to give my opinion as to the type of building which should be provided. There are no buildings on the Reserve at the present time which could be used even temporarily for school purposes or a teacher's residence.

The foregoing report is respectfully submitted.

You will readily appreciate therefore how difficult it would be to make provision in the estimates of this year for the construction of a school at Nut Lake, or for that matter, at any other reserve throughout the Dominion. Provision is usually made for the construction of Indian day schools in the regular estimates which, as I have already intimated, are prepared early in the fall of each year.

Provision has been made this year for the construction of two schools on the Big River reserve, one at Mistawasis and one at Thunderchild. If in your judgment however the need at Nut Lake is more urgent than it is, say, at Thunderchild, a recommendation could be made to the Minister to have the appropriation for Thunderchild transferred to Nut Lake.

The erection of an Indian day school on the

Dear Sir:

Ref: Your 121-8-1 of March 9th, Educational Facilities, Nut Lake Reserve.

I beg to advise that last week I visited the Nut Lake Reserve on the day of Treaty payment and discussed school matters with the Indians.

The conditions on this Reserve are that they have as fine an agricultural Reserve as there is in the Province—at least 1,000 acres of land could be broken without any brushing, but the Indians themselves are doing practically no farming. They are trying to make their living by hunting, trapping, and seneca root. The Indians themselves can no longer make a living in this way, and must turn to agriculture. There are a number, I believe, who would take up agriculture if they had horses and implements, but they would also need some assistance in the way of rations the first year to live on while getting their land broken.

The housing conditions are very bad. There are only three houses on the Reserve. The rest are simply shacks with mud roofs and floors. Mr. Waddy placed $5,000.00 in his 1939-40 estimates for assistance on this Reserve. He also has about 500 logs which he had the Indians take out in exchange for food supplies during the past two winters. These are splendid building logs, and it would require from 36 to 40 of them for a house. None of the Indians are carpenters, consequently a foreman would have to be brought in. Mr. Waddy had an Indian from another Reserve building a granary when I was there. This man was employing two or three of the local men as assistants, and would be quite competent to act as foreman for the building of Indian homes.

With regard to the religious aspect, while paying the Treaty Mr. Waddy took a census, and these Indians all profess to be Pagan, except 5, five of whom are R.C. and one Protestant. There are about 70 children of school age on this Reserve, only one being in school or receiving any education.

Mr. Waddy has discussed this matter with the R.C. prelate of this Reserve, who suggested that there was room enough for two schools, one on each end of the Reserve. At a meeting of the Indians, strong exception was taken by many of them to any religious training in the school, and it is my opinion that a school along the lines suggested (that is, with a teacher giving no religious instruction, but with each church having the privilege of going in and giving religious instruction during certain hours, but not compulsory) is the only way we can hope to establish a school and get the children to attend at present.

I will, however, personally interview the R.C. prelate, either before or immediately after my next meeting with this Band, and submit another report.

Yours truly,

Thos. Robertson,

Regina, June 19, 1939.

Dear Sir:

Re: Your #121-8-1 of March 9th, Educational Facilities, Nut Lake Reserve.

It will be noted in my report of June 13th, covering my last visit to this Reserve, that I asked the Indians to discuss the above matters among themselves, stating I would meet them again after they had considered them.

On Thursday, June 15th, I received a wire from the Farming Instructor, stating that the Band wished to meet me on Saturday, June 17th, as they were all leaving to dig senega root on Sunday the 18th. On Saturday morning I left Regina at 6 a.m., taking Mr. Reichman with me owing to bad conditions of the road. I visited the Reserve and returned to Regina at 4 a.m. Sunday morning.

On arriving at the Reserve, I found that a great many of the Indians had already gone, the Chief and one of the Councillors and about half a dozen of the Band being still there. The following matters were discussed: Education, homes, farming, etc.

Education: The Councillor expressed himself as strongly in favour of a day school. The others present were also in favour, but they claimed they had not had an opportunity to discuss it fully with the Band, and that the Band would not be all together again until haymaking started, and asked that a decision be deferred until that time.

Homes: As pointed out in my previous report, there are only three homes on the Reserve. At our previous meeting, we had

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

pointed out......
pointed out that while we admitted that homes were necessary and we would do everything possible to secure assistance to build those homes, they must build on locations approved by us and those locations must be within a mile or a mile and a half of the Department buildings. At this meeting, objection was made to these requirements, only three or four being willing to comply. We again pointed out to them that they admitted themselves they must take up agriculture in order to earn a living, and that by locating in a central part of the Reserve, they would receive a great deal more assistance and supervision. They would not require so many implements, nor would the wear and tear on them be so great. Our medical officer would be able to see them much more easily and give them better service. We pointed out that the requirements we had specified were solely for their own benefit, and under those circumstances we could not grant any assistance unless the requirements were complied with.

As pointed out before, they have over 500 splendid spruce building logs, perfectly straight, about 20 feet in length, averaging about 8 inches at the butt and 6 inches at the top. The Chief and Councillor expressed themselves as favourable to our requirements and are going to discuss the matter further with the objecting members. I have asked Mr. Waddy to send in requisitions to meet the requirements and I trust the Department will be able to give some assistance this season.

Farming: As pointed out in my previous report, there is nothing but ponies on this Reserve, which are of no use for breaking land. A number of the Band expressed themselves as very anxious to do some breaking this season. The Chief, a good Indian, who formerly did considerable farming, informed me that he would take it up again if he received some assistance. He also assured me that several others would do the same, and asked that he be supplied with five teams of horses this season. After discussing the matter with Mr. Waddy, we explained to them that our funds were very limited, that it would be useless to ask the Department for five teams this season, but if they would agree to work together, we would try and get the Department to supply them with three teams and harness this season, and if they satisfied us that they would farm, we would try to give them some more horses next season; but that if the horses were supplied, they would belong to the Department, and if we found they were not being properly cared for or were being misused, they would be immediately taken away from them. They agreed to this, and I would recommend, if funds are at all available, that they be supplied with three teams of horses and harness, as I believe they would make an honest effort to improve their conditions.

The conditions......
The conditions of these people are pitiful. They have no homes. Their women and children are ragged, and they are finding it very, very hard to secure food supplies.

I am satisfied this Band will support a school. I am also satisfied that, with a good man and woman who would take an interest in them and work with them, great improvements could be made. I have not much hope of very much improvement under the present Farming Instructor. He has not the proper temperament, nor have the Indians any confidence or trust in him. The Chief pressed very strongly for another Farming Instructor.

Yours truly,
