Dear Mr. Nicholson:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of June 10, in which you seek information with respect to educational facilities at the Nut Lake Indian Reserve, Touchwood Agency, Saskatchewan.

The last census (1933) indicates that there are 289 Indians living on the reserve lands at Nut Lake. This is one of the most primitive bands anywhere in the Dominion. They appear to be vigorously opposed to missionary effort and consequently opposed to the enrolment of their children at Indian residential schools, which schools, as you are no doubt aware, are conducted by the Department in co-operation with the churches. Our records indicate that a number of investigations of conditions on this reserve have been undertaken by our inspectors, in co-operation with the Indian agents. The desirability of establishing an Indian day school on the reserve was thoroughly investigated by Inspector Murison in 1935. In his report the Inspector states:

"I have discussed this matter with Indian Agent Waddy and find that he holds the same views as myself with regard to the attitude of the Nut Lake Indians towards education - that is that their attitude has not changed. They are strongly opposed to any interference with their aboriginal beliefs. ...... I was in charge of this reserve as Indian agent for over 15 years. During that period I made a very determined effort to recruit children from the Nut Lake Band for the residential schools in the Touchwood and Qu'Appelle agencies, but with very little success. I think during that period I was only successful in obtaining three or four recruits. ...... These Indians appear to be contented with their present mode of living and the only request they made to me during the many years I was there was that they be left alone."

REPORT ON INSPECTION OF TOUCHWOOD INDIAN AGENCY

Nut Lake Reserve;

As you are aware, this is a very backward reserve. I do not know the exact number of Indians on this reservation but it is somewhere around 325. Out of this number only two can speak English, the Chief's wife who came from the Ote reserve, Ramsack, and was educated at the Regina Industrial School, and an Indian who was educated in the United States. It is hard to realize we have this number of Indians on a reservation surrounded by white people and only two out of the 325 speak the language of the country they are living in. However, it is easily understood as there has never been a school on the reserve and very few of the children are sent to boarding schools because the Indians are opposed to this. In the past they have mostly been hunters and for years their nearest railway station was Wadena. I think Rose Valley is only about fifteen or sixteen years old, that is when the railway came in. For this reason the Indians were more or less isolated but of course since the railway came in the country has been opened and now you are in a thickly populated settlement no matter which way you go from Nut Lake reserve. A great many of the Indians have from time to time worked for white farmers and no doubt understand a little English but the time has now come when we should try to establish a school on the reserve. After what I have seen take place on the Chagoness reserve in the Duck Lake Agency I think we should try to do the same on Nut Lake. The Indians on both reserves originally belonged to the same tribe. I spoke to the Indians before I left about establishing a school on the reserve and pointed out to them it was a pity to let their children grow up in ignorance. However, I informed them they could not expect anything at the present time but I was sure as soon as the war was over our Branch would take steps to build a school on the reservation providing I had their assurance they would support the school by sending their children there. I hope when the time comes this matter will have the attention of our Branch.

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

Dear Sir:

I have just had a visit from some Indians, pouring out their woes, troubles, and injustices, and requesting that I write you in regard to some of these things. It has always been a source of grief to me to see the treatment the Indians here have received at the hands of the white man. They have no more educational facilities than they had 100 years before the white man came. A young Indian will grow up to manhood before he has a name or can speak a word of English. There has been no school or church as a means of education on either line either secular or religious. They still follow the ways of their ancestors, and when one takes sick, they sing continuously to drive the evil spirits away. I have heard them at it, but the patients died. If they violate the white man's law they are sent to jail, that is the extent of their education, the jail is their only school. The white man has not helped them morally either. A boy and girl decide to live together, and that is all there is to that. A few years ago, 4 or possibly 5, a man of perhaps 40 left his wife and family and lived with a young girl. The wife, who had a number of children, appealed to the white man's law. It was to have him support the family. She was told nothing could be done about it as they had never been married. A year or so later she had a child, and when the Dr. asked who was the child's father, she said "Birch! Birch!" I was told the Indians got rid of him as he was too much squaw and I was informed he was transferred to another reservation. Morals! God help us! Now the man who made the complaint told me that they had it in for him as the police in Kelvington was a particular friend of Birch. Now this man, whose name is Bluecloud, had arranged with a farmer near Kelvington for himself and boy and team to go threshing. The man was to meet him there would drive in with the car to let him know when they would start. A car drove in and Bluecloud went to see the man, thinking it was his man. He stumbled over the tent rope and nearly fell. The police had been informed that there were Indians drinking around there, so when Bluecloud stumbled over the tent rope the Police grabbed him saying "you are drunk" and ordered him to get into the car, which he did. He was not drunk as his wife can testify, but the state of the police may be questioned as the "drunk"? had to tell him he was going in the wrong direction. He was kept in jail (in school if you like it better) for several days, then the Inspector arrived, and the prisoner heard him from his cell say, "Well, if he is stubborn (he stoutly denied being drunk) we will give him a heavier sentence. He managed to get a lawyer who, after conferring with them, told him he better plead guilty as they were going to give him two months if he pleaded not guilty (quite a school) and he would (by telling a lie) get off with 30 days. He did as his schoolmaster told him, and got 30 days. He turned to his persecutor, not prosecutor, and asked what they would do with his wife and family, 7 in all. Oh, we will take care of them. Well he was taken to Regina where he spent 30 days, during which time the threshing was over, and his chance to earn at 10 days $150.00. His wife was given an order for $5.00 on a store. Now my contention is that the Government of this country owes Bluecloud an apology, and $150.00 in cash, and nothing less than the
would be justice. I know this man well. He is a University man, got his education in the U.S. He is a temperate man, does not smoke or use vile language, but he knows when he gets a dirty deal from the whites. He was a veteran of the first World War, was shot in the knee, which, of course, helps to make a "drunk" out of him as it is hard for him to walk without a slight limp. We talk of the Germans and the Japs, and their injustices, but I think it is time Canada cleaned up her own front yard. If this thing is not straightened up I intend to take it to Ottawa, and then to some of our newspapers who are always willing to print any such article if the writer signs his name to it. If Birch is still drawing good Canadian money for taking care of squaws whose husbands have deserted them, the people of this country should know it. If all the education in morals, religion, and secular matters are left to the jails, unjust judges, and immoral agents, then it is time for a change, and time for a house-cleaning. Now a personal word. I am near 75 years of age, and don't want trouble with anyone, but when downtrodden, oppressed people come to me asking me to speak up in their behalf, I am still ready to fight.

Hoping to hear from you, I remain,

Yours truly,

Sgd. R.J. Laing.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 18th instant, File No. 121-8-1 (T.T.), in connection with the proposed Indian Day School at Nut Lake.

I visited the Nut Lake Reserve on the 24th instant accompanied by Indian Agent R.S. Davis, for the purpose of discussing with Mr. Davis, Farming Instructor Cervais, and the Indians, the matter of establishing a day school on that reserve.

The Nut Lake Indians seem to be anxious to have a day school but they insist that it be non-denominational, the same as the one on the Kinistino Reserve. Very few of the Nut Lake Indians have accepted Christianity and no Christian Church has been successful in its efforts to become established amongst them.

Many day schools are needed in this province and the need should be filled at all those reserves at the earliest possible date. I do not think it would be advisable to give priority to the Nut Lake Indians in view of the fact that a number of other reserves where day schools are required will have better attendance than will the Nut Lake Indians, the reason being that many of the Nut Lake Indians are away from their homes a considerable part of the year hunting, trapping, and performing casual labour, there being no other way for the Indians to make a living on that reserve at the present time. Most of the reserves where I have asked for the establishment of day schools have a large proportion of the Indians earning their living on the reserve by farming. On those reserves the Indians are not travelling so much and it would not be so difficult to keep up good attendance in the schools.

I may say that as soon as I commenced discussing the school question with the Nut Lake Indians on this occasion they immediately asked for a residential school of their own citing as their reason the fact that they do not live at home very much. Of course I informed them that the department would not consider giving them a residential school for their reserve.

An effort is being made to commence farming on a much larger scale on the Nut Lake Reserve than has been done in the past and I hope that before many years a day school there will be more useful than at the present time.

With reference to the letter on the same file which was addressed to Indian Agent R.S. Davis and copy sent to me, with regard to the approximate cost of a one-room day school at Nut Lake, I discussed with the Nut Lake Indians and the Farming Instructor the possibility of getting out a fairly large quantity of saw logs this winter to be sawn into lumber and used for the building of a day school on their reserve, also buildings for the Farming Instructor which were asked for in the Estimates for 1947-48. If this is done, and I have reason to believe it will be done, the amount of $3,000.00 which you mention would probably be sufficient to build the classroom building, as well as the teacher's residence and out-buildings for a day school. I would suggest that the $3,000.00 be added to the Touchwood Agency Estimates, that if the Indians get out logs and get a sufficient quantity sawn to provide all the necessary rough lumber for buildings needed on their reserve, they be given first consideration for a day school. Ottawa, September 27th, 1947.

Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander, Inspector of Indian Agencies, Regina, Saskatchewan.

Recently we received a request from Indian Agent Davis for $1,000 for labour in connection with the new day school on the Nut Lake Reserve.

We have not yet been able to send him this money as we have not obtained the Order in Council establishing this school as provided by Section 9 of the Indian Act.

We are aware that Mr. Davis has a school under construction on the Nut Lake Reserve but the information on our file regarding it is extremely vague.

I would, therefore, appreciate hearing from you as soon as possible giving us a complete picture of how the matter stands.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
AT THE GOVERNMENT HOUSE AT OTTAWA
TUESDAY, the 23rd day of SEPTEMBER, 1947.

PRESENT:

HIS EXCELLENCY
THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

WHEREAS the Acting Minister of Mines and Resources reports that there are thirty-five (35) Indian children of school age on the Nut Lake Reserve, Touchwood Indian Agency, Province of Saskatchewan, for whom educational facilities are required; and

THAT funds are available in Vote 181, 1947-48, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, for the establishment of a day school for these children.

NOW, THEREFORE, His Excellency the Governor General in Council, on the recommendation of the Acting Minister of Mines and Resources and in accordance with the provisions of Section 9 (a) of the Indian Act, Chapter 98, 1927, is pleased to establish and doth hereby establish a day school on the Nut Lake Reserve, Touchwood Indian Agency, Province of Saskatchewan to be known as the "Nut Lake Indian Day School".

I wish to report that on my recent trip to the Nut Lake Reserve, I found they hadn't poured the cement for the basement for the school on account of the cold weather.

The frames are all completed but I advised them not to pour the cement until they had further advice from us as I feel we would run up against the cement crumbling after it is poured in, and I do not think it would be advisable to proceed unless we have the proper equipment to heat the gravel, water, and some way to keep the cement warm until it has dried out.

If this cannot be completed this year and have to start in the Spring, do you think I should get a requisition out for the material we will have to buy and store it. This would mean we would be spending the money out of this year's appropriation.

With reference to Department letter of the 27th September, 1947, 121-8-1 (WT 1), I have to say that action was taken to complete the basement and concrete work for the new Day School at the Nut Lake Reserve in an effort to have the concrete work completed before cold weather set in, in the hope that the remainder of the work will be finished early in the Spring.

The concrete frames are all completed but only part of the cement work was completed before the weather became too cold.

I am enclosing copy of a letter from Indian Agent, Mr. R. S. Davis, reporting on the work to do, and I would ask that instructions be given Mr. Davis as to the preparation of a Requisition with a view to purchasing the material this winter in order that the work may be done promptly in the Spring.

Dec 23, 1947.

J.P.B. Ostrander Esq., Inspector of Indian Agencies, Regina, Sask.

Enclosed herewith requisition for flooring for the new school on the Nut Lake Reserve.

When getting prices, I ordered this flooring to be shipped as the supply is limited. Prices have gone up. I secured this at a very reasonable price, being about the same as edged grain fir is today.

I had no authority for doing so, but could see where we could save considerable, and may not have been able to secure it later.

The above price is the same as I paid for the Farm Instructor's house.

R.S. Davis,

December 23, 1947.

J.P.B. Ostrander Esq., Inspector of Indian Agencies, Regina, Sask.

G.A.Havers,
Agency Clerk.

It has been very difficult to purchase hardwood flooring and Mr. Davis was successful in locating sufficient flooring for the school.

Please give approval for Mr. Davis to make local purchase in accordance with the requisition enclosed and to voucher for the same at once. The flooring will be stored and held in a safe place until the spring.

R. S. Davis,

Ottawa, February 27, 1948.

Mr. R.S. Davis, Indian Agent, Punnichy, Saskatchewan.

Nut Lake Indian Day School.

In the standard bill of materials for a one-room Day School there are listed three separate types of furnaces and other heating materials for three separate sets of climates. First set is for a school in "A" temperature range or from 0 to 70 degrees. The second is for "B" range or with temperature from minus 15 to 70 degrees. The third is for "C" range or with a temperature from minus 30 to 70 degrees.

I am advised by our Lands and Development Services Branch that the Nut Lake School is considered to be in the "C" range and therefore, the bill of materials for this particular temperature range should be provided. You will find this information also on Hl of Index No. 837 of the drawings for a one room Indian Day School with teacher's residence. The requisition which you have submitted is for a furnace which will provide approximately (19,000 btu), about 10 percent more than the specifications require. I have consulted our heating Engineers and they advise that the furnace quoted on by Mr. Brockman will be quite satisfactory. Would you please discuss the above information with Mr. Brockman and advise whether his quotation includes registers, etc., as required for temperature range "C" (minus 30 to 70 degrees as per specifications and blueprints). If so could we please be advised so that these requisitions can also be sent over to the Departmental Purchasing Agent.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, February 26, 1948.

(a) We have deleted the hardwood flooring as Purchase Order No. 25726 covers this item.

It is suggested that you mix two gallons of white with four gallons of pale blue to provide a very pale blue for these two rooms. We have also specified that the concrete paint be aluminum in colour as we have found that this gives a very light colour to the basement and also reflects light rays.
I would also ask that we be advised when the school is about half completed so that we can arrange to order the blackboards and also the desks. Both of these items are in very short supply and will take approximately six to eight weeks for delivery.

Bernard F. Neary,

Dear Sir:

We regret our delay in answering your phone call for our bid on the heating & electrical contracts on the proposed Indian school at Punnichy. We have had some difficulty in obtaining prices. Below is our estimated costs.

| Item                                      | Cost   |
|-------------------------------------------|--------|
| 1 - #30-25 Hecla furnace and double casing | 275.00 |
| 900 lbs iron made up and erected          | 315.00 |
| Registers and faces                       | 60.00  |
| 200 sq ft of asbestos put on              | 15.00  |
| Quadrant damper sets                      | 29.30  |
| Labor in setting up furnace and registers | 40.00  |

$ 734.30

Should #24 gauge metal be not available, aluminum will be used at a slight extra cost. We cannot guarantee the above furnace will satisfactorily heat the building if the layout on the plans is followed. You will notice that the plans call for over a thousand square inches of hot air and only just over four hundred square inches of cold air. This is definitely going to starve the cold air and reduce the efficiency of the furnace. By installing more cold airs you will receive a great deal more economy from the unit. Ed. Tax is not included in the above estimate and will be extra.

We would not like to quote on the electrical work at this time as we will need more information. There were no exit lites shown on the plans and no fire alarm system. We believe that the Fire Commissioner will definitely want these installed and the plans for the wiring, fire alarm system will have to be O.K ed by his office. If this could be accomplished and the plans returned to us we would like to bid on the electrical work.

Trusting that this is the information you require,

Yours truly,

Wynyard Heating & Electric,

per (sgd) W.B. Martin.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.
